characters: A DAZZLE OF SUNLIGHT FILLING THE SCREEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woven image on the tapestry gives way to a pair of white unicorns browsing in a sun-dappled glade.  A male and female, these animals are of surpassing beauty, their tapered, spiraling horns glowing like precious metal. Their movements are so graceful that every other living creature seems clumsy by comparison.  The SOUND of a distant hunting horn makes them pause.  A second NOTE is heard.  The unicorns drift, silent and languid, into the farther reaches of the forest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hunting horn SOUNDS a third time.  A young woman stil close to childhood, fifteen at most, turns back to look a the castle in the distance.  A troop of armed men rides out hunting, accompanied by braying hounds and the blare of horns.  One of the company is masked and dressed all i black. The girl's name is LILI.  She is a princess of the distan castle and dressed in splendid brocades and silk.  In her arms, she carries a bouquet of wildflowers wrapped in a lace napkin.  Like these blossoms, she herself is young and fresh and innocent.  She sings a simple country air a she runs through the waving grass toward the deep woods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On an emerald patch of moss in the shade beneath the spreading limbs of chestnuts and oaks, numbers of small animals gambol.  Squirrels and rabbits, hedgehogs and foxes, all manner of creatures leap and frolic about the feet of a curious young man.  This is JACK O' THE GREEN. His hair is long and unshorn and he wears a costume woven from ivy leaves, skins and vines.  On his feet are bark sandals.  His features are tanned berry-brown and woven into his tangled locks is a wreath of flowers.  He is a legendary "Green Man" or "Wild Man" who lives the free life of a hermit alone in the deep woods. Jack, the "Green Man," feeds morsels of bread and fruit t the animals dancing around his feet.  He is a friend to all the beasts of the forest and carries food for them in a split-willow basket.  Birds fly down and land on his head and shoulders, taking seeds and nuts from his lips. The musical sound of someone approaching alerts him.  His eyes have an animal quickness and his instincts are as finely tuned as any creature of the wild.  The birds fly from his shoulders to the treetops.  His furred companion dart for cover.  In three quick bounds, Jack is himself u a nearby tree, clinging to a high branch like a cat. The Princess Lili comes singing down the path.  She spots the fallen willow basket and looks around for the Green Man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack... Hello, Jack... There is no answer.  Puzzled, Lili sits on the moss, puts aside her flowers, and rummages through the contents of the basket.  The dried apples, walnuts and sunflowers don't occupy her for long.  She is annoyed.  A princess i not someone to trifle with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack-o'-the-Green...?  Green Jack? Oh bother, I know you're here.  Why are you so cruel? Unseen, high in his tree, Jack-o'-the-Green watches the young princess.  He is amused by her anger but there is nothing malicious about his smile.  He climbs quietly to lower branch, hangs suspended for a moment, then drops. Jack lands close to the unsuspecting girl.  Startled, she screams in surprise.  Jack laughs at her unwarranted terror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greetings, my lady, the green wood is honored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Jack, you are a wild man to use me so. Jack spies the bouquet of wildflowers and reaches for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you like. Jack gathers up the bouquet, bowing low as he jumps to hi feet.  A bluebird flies out of the greenery and lands on his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the bird)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She brings a gift as fair as herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Green Man and the Princess wander together down a meandering path.  Birds circle about them and numbers of small animals scamper shyly at their heels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You promised!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you did... you did!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I may have said perhaps...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liar!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or perchance... The distant BLARE of a hunting horn interrupts them.  The animals freeze, wild-eyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my father, gone a-hunting.  The Baron Couer de Noir is his guest and must be provided with some sport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sport, indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Baron is a frightful man.  They say he's an ogre.  He wears a mask so none may see his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blackheart.  Aptly named.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, fie.  What about the unicorn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unicorn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A promise is a sacred oath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.  I'll show you something sacred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small meadow:  a sun-gilded amphitheater within the darker confines of the forest.  At its edge flows a gentl stream.  An evil-looking viper moves sinuously along the grassy back as Jack and Lili step from the concealing shrubbery nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's rest a minute.  I'm so thirsty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop complaining.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gentleman would offer water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only were he a fool to boot. (pointing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See yon viper?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shuddering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I detest serpents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That viper has envenomed the water. No animal will drink here now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What shall we do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be patient. They crouch together behind the shrubbery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've lost my napkin.  It was all elf-work and lace... I must have dropped it when you startled me so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go search for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't leave me now.  I fear the unicorn won't show himself without you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not its master.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (touching his arm)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The napkin will keep.  I'd rather not be alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your command is my wish, Princess Lili.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pair of ferocious hounds bray under the tree in which Jack was hiding.  Another sniffs at a few scattered blossoms and Lili's lace napkin lying forgotten on the moss. The hunting party rides up at a gallop.  At the head of the troops are Lili's father, KING GODWIN, pink-cheeked and white-bearded; a kind-hearted, elfish man, though wea and ineffectual; and BARON COUER DE NOIR, a powerful knight on a black charger.  His greaves and breastplate are black as midnight as is the heavy cloak which envelop him.  His hands are covered with black gauntlets and a horned black hood with a wolf's lupine features masks his face.  His voice rumbles with dread authority as the part reins to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What spoor have the hounds for us? A lance-bearer dismounts and takes the lace kerchief from the dog's foaming mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My daughter's napkin.  That's certain. The Baron unstraps a crossbow from his saddle leathers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We proceed.  Have three men restrain the dogs.  Don't come until you hear the horns. The hunters ride on, leaving the dog handlers to control the straining hounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lili and Jack wait behind the bushes, watching the stream

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much longer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am a princess.  You have no right to order me about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In these woods you are a commoner. Now be quiet.  True royalty approaches.

dialogues.speaker: THE STREAM
dialogues.text: The pair of radiant white unicorns pushes through the undergrowth to the edge of the stream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ohhhh... they're so beautiful... The male unicorn bends his head and dips his golden horn into the stream.  Soon after, the female begins to drink and numbers of small animals, rabbits, mice, and squirrels, creep from under cover to drink as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The alicorn purifies the water, purging it of all poison.

dialogues.speaker: JACK AND LILI
dialogues.text: The princess is entranced.  A look of utter rapture illuminates her features.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Such grace... and their smell; it's ambrosia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They rival the angels of paradise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Jack, mightn't I touch one?  It would thrill me so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you honest?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tis a fair question.  If you be a virtuous maid the unicorn will lay his head in your lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll not flee if I show myself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not if you be chaste.  Tis an awesome test of virginity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've no fear of failure.  Your implications are most unbecoming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not your judge... nor have I any desire to witness the trial. Jack turns to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To fetch your napkin. Jack pushes through the underbrush and is lost from sight For a moment, the princess is confused and nervous at being left alone in such circumstances, but she peers out at the unicorns and the sight of such beauty rekindles he resolve. Princess Lili steps out of the concealing underbrush and walks slowly to the center of the clearing.  Her bearing is noble and proud, her carriage utterly dignified. The unicorns lift their heads from the stream and watch the girl's progress.  The other smaller animals cease drinking and scatter into hiding. Lili sits on the grass in the center of the clearing, spreading her gown around her.  She smiles at the staring unicorns. The male unicorn grows agitated.  His nostrils flare; the strong neck arches.  Sunlight gleams on the shaft of his golden horn as he prances across the stream to the meadow sending multi-hued clouds of butterflies aloft from the flowers underfoot. Lili smiles at the nimble dancing of the unicorn, seemingly drawn to her by an invisible lead.  He rears up whinnying in protest, but the lure is too strong, something unspoken compels him toward the smiling girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack hurries along the overgrown path, running as numbly as a wild stag.  The SOUND of approaching HOOFBEATS bring him up short.  With the instincts of an animal, Jack dart into concealment.  After a moment, the hunting party ride past, sunlight glinting on the steel lance-tips.  The Baron holds his crossbow at the ready, as black and grim as Death himself. When the hunters are gone from sight, Jack hurries form his hiding-place.  He realizes something is terribly wron and runs back through the woods, leaping rocks and deadfall logs in a desperate attempt to reach the clearin before them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The princess makes no move as the trembling unicorn stand before her, the tip of his rapier-sharp horn pressed against her breast.  At this moment, he could kill her in an instant, yet she does not resist or show any fear. Instead, she smiles with joy. Slowly, the unicorn kneels; first folding his forelegs, then settling his hindquarters onto the grass.  His limpi eye meets Lili's adoring gaze.  Without a sound, he settles his great head in the virgin's lap, his long whit mane spreading over her like a shawl.

dialogues.speaker: LILI AND THE UNICORN
dialogues.text: The girl strokes the unicorn's head, running her hand lovingly down the spiraling horn.  The animal seems totally in her power.  He closes his eyes and nuzzles her bodice.  Almost without thinking, Princess Lili unbuttons the top of her gown, exposing her pale breasts.  The entranced unicorn immediately begins to suckle like a newborn creature.  Lili hugs the white head to her bosom, consumed by ecstasy and bliss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: King Godwin, the Baron and his cohorts ride silently up t the edge of the clearing, screened from view by the surrounding trees.  The Baron holds up his gloved hand an hisses a whispered command:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold! The other riders rein to a stop.  The Baron guides his horse closer to the edge of the clearing, parting the branches which conceal him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through a fringe of leaves the Baron sees the Princess nursing the reclining unicorn, a tableaux at once reminiscent of the Madonna and the Infant Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: THE BARON
dialogues.text: As he inserts a bolt in his crossbow and cranks back the string until it is taut.  Placing the weapon to his shoulder, the Baron takes careful aim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lili croons to the unicorn resting on her breast, a primitive melody born of joy.  All at once, the sibilant SOUND of an arrow's slicing passage rends the still air. The crossbow bolt strikes the unicorn in the neck.  The startled outcry of the wounded beast is far more scream than whinny. The unicorn bounds to his feet, spraying the Princess wit his bright blood.  She is torn from her happy reverie by the violence of the act.  Her own outcry merges with the animal's wail of pain. The wounded unicorn, followed by his mate, gallops for freedom across the clearing. The black Baron bursts from the far side of the meadow an thunders after the fleeing unicorns.  King Godwin is righ behind, followed by his retinue of lance-bearing hunters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screaming)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!  God!  Father, no! The horsemen gallop out of sight, accompanied by the call of the hunting horn and much eager shouting. Jack crashes through the underbrush surrounding the clearing and rushes to the side of the anguished Lili, wh cowers, replacing her blood-soaked bodice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (furious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  They've hurt the unicorn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father and the Baron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damned hunters.  It was a trap, and you were the bait!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know... I didn't... (sobbing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was so lovely... he was in my lap like... like a baby... and... I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They tricked you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My own father...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How bad was the unicorn's wound?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It happened so fast.  He was hurt and ran away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He did run?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, and the mare with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.  They'll never catch him. There's not a mount in the kingdom can outrun a unicorn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flecked with froth and blood, the male unicorn bursts fro a thicket in full flight.  Wild-eyed, the female is right behind.  They pause for a moment, sides heaving as they gasp for air.  In the distance, the SOUNDS of braying hounds and the musical NOTE of the hunting horn start the running again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Led by the Baron and the red-eyed hounds, the hunting party thunders through the woods in full pursuit of the unicorns. One of the riders has a hunting horn coiled around his shoulder.  He blows a single, sustained NOTE as he gallop past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pool is a crystalline jewel, surrounded by moss- covered stones, the tranquil water reflecting the overhanging trees.  Lili kneels by the edge, washing the blood from her embroidered dress.  Jack watches her, reclining on a gnarled tree-root nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are many would pay a king's ransom for a few drops of unicorn blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want it on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Its powers are strong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to be reminded of what happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think memory can be washed away like a few spots of blood?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The war-like SOUNDS of the hunting party grow nearer as the two unicorns pause in their flight to drink from the stream.  Tenderly, the mare nuzzles the stallion's neck near where the dart cruelly rends his flesh.  The two animals exchange a look of understanding.  The situation is desperate, their pursuers very near.  The stallion motions upstream with his head and his mate sadly comprehends.  She starts slowly up stream, looking back over her shoulder.  The hunting horn BLARES, nearer still The stallion whinnies at the mare and she replies before plunging up the stream to safety while her mate remains behind awaiting his destiny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hounds are frantic now, the scent very strong.  They lope ahead of the riders, baying like demons from hell. The Baron is right behind, leading the hunters in a daredevil chase through the woods.  In their helmets and chain mail, with steel-tipped lances glinting on high, they are as fearsome as an army of fiends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahead, through the trees, the wounded male unicorn is glimpsed standing alone by the stream.  The dogs' howling grows furious.  The hunters SHOUT and BELLOW.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dogs break from the forest and hurl themselves at the unicorn.  With a swift jab, the stallion impales the firs hound on his horn and sends him flying.  Just as the pack of hunters emerges from the woods, the unicorn takes off, leaping over the heads of the snarling hounds, darting away between the trees.  The hunters and their dogs are i close pursuit, eager now for the kill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lili and Jack sit among the roots and mossy rocks bordering the still ponds.  A shaft of golden light angle down through the cathedral arching of tree limbs above them.  Lili's dress is cleansed of blood and she reclines against a tree trunk, sadly singing a simple ballad in a clear, soprano voice.  Jack is entranced.  His teasing look has transformed into a gaze of utter adoration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once there was a lady fair, Rode out on her milk-white steed; Roses and dewdrops woven in her hair And in her heart:  the devil's seed. Sweet William did a-hunting go, All in the deep wood where faeries dwell. From dawn til dark roamed he to and fro Lost, O lost, all under their spell. Came he at last to where bluebells grow, And he heard them ring, tis true to tell. And he lay him down and did not know The flower's sound was his own death knell. For while he slept came the lady fair, And gathered him up behind her saddle. Now, all ye young hunters, of bluebells beware; For Sweet William rode straight through the gates of Hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A broad river flows toward the sea, divided into multi- branched channels across acres and mud flats.  The surf curls and crashes in the distance.  Shore birds probe the muck with their curved bills. The wounded unicorn breaks from the green line of trees along the edge of the estuary.  The SOUNDS of dogs and hunting horns can be heard close behind.  Without pausing the stallion gallops frantically out onto the mud flats. The unicorn's sides are streaked with blood and sweat.  A bright-red froth bubbles on his nostrils.  His eyes are wide with panic. The thick mud underfoot sucks at the unicorn's galloping hooves.  All at once, the unicorn stumbles and falls, cartwheeling in the muck.  He struggles to regain his feet, but slips again, floundering. The hunters ride out of the trees and rein-in at the edge of the estuary.  The howling dogs struggle across the mud toward the fallen unicorn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lili and Jack under the tree.  The princess smiles at the adoring boy, toying with her golden ring, which she pulls on and off her finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not even the birds sing sweet as you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack... Green Jack, you mustn't flatter me so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tis the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A maid must beware of flattery... Methinks you want to kiss me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no happier thought under heaven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I were your bride, would the kissing ever stop...?  Do you wish to marry me, Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My lady mocks me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nay, Jack, I'm but wary of your intentions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My heart intends no more than that you love me as I do you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, la...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The unicorn struggles in the mud, hopelessly mired, when the dog packs converges upon it.  Baying and snarling, th dogs surround the stallion, nipping and harrying.  The unicorn fights back, thrusting his terrible horn, impalin an unwary hound that ventured too close. The hunters watch from the bank, awaiting their leader's command to close in for the kill.  The Baron dismounts, holding his crossbow.  He hands his reins to King Godwin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The quarry is at bay.  Attend me here while I make the kill. Black cloak whipping in the wind, the masked Baron stride out onto the mud flats, relentless as the specter of Death. The sky above darkens.  Black storm clouds gather and the ominous RUMBLE of thunder troubles the grim landscape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The light has changed.  It is darker now.  A distant peal of thunder is HEARD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid it may storm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let it.  Haven't you a cozy bower we might hide in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tis not fit for a princess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be it fit for your wife, Green Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, perchance you'll me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If wishes were horses even beggars would ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you wish it, Jack? (showing him her ring)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wish you this our wedding band?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if I answer yes?  Will my wish come true? Laughing, Lili throws her ring high over their heads. Tracing a golden arc through the air, the ring lands with a splash in the center of the pond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fetch my ring and you may take me for your wife. It is obvious from her mocking attitude that Lili is teasing, but Jack is serious.  He strips off his leaf-and fur vestments and dives headlong into the pond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Baron's heavy black boots splash across the shallow water of the estuary as he bears down on the harried unicorn.  The frantic trapped stallion is within range no and the Baron lifts his crossbow to his shoulder, the wol mask leering and demonic as he takes aim. The Baron fires.  The bolt strikes the unicorn's flank, piercing his ribs.  A froth of lung-blood foams into the mud.  The stallion screams.  His frightened eye is bright and staring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slowly, the golden ring drifts downward, tumbling end- over-end in a lazy spiral to the dark and muddy bottom. Jack's pale, near-naked form stabs through the crystal water, a trail of silver bubbles streaming in his wake like a comet's tail.  He strokes down into the murk, tendrils of water-weed swirling about him.  In the distance, the tantalizing glint of the drifting ring lure him on. The ring settles into the mud on the bottom, concealed by waving weeds and algae.  Jack searches blindly for it, groping with his hands as billowing clouds of silt rise about him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The black clouds boil and crash, thunderheads mounting on upon another in a dark maelstrom.  Jagged lightning split the sky.  The heavens are in a tumult.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Baron's dark figure looms over the fallen unicorn. His gloved hand reaches out and grasps the ivory horn, wrenching back the animal's head.  The Baron's glove smolders and burns as if the horn was a white-hot poker. The stallion's shrill whinny is cut short when the Baron lops off his head with a single, brutal stroke of his broadsword. The ROAR of thunder seems to crack the sky apart.  For a long moment, the Baron stands holding his grisly, drippin trophy by the single horn, staring up at the raging dark sky as his black cloak whips about him in the ferocious wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His lungs about to burst, Jack can no longer continue the search for the ring.  He turns and looks up at the surfac which has grown quite dark.  With frantic strokes, he races upward only to bump his head into something solid a the top.  Terribly frightened, he finds the surface covered by a sheet of ice. Jack pounds his fist against the obstructing ice and succeeds in punching through it, thrusting his gasping head out into the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bewildered, Jack crashes through the ice towards shore. The woods have changed utterly.  In place of the bountifu foliage of midsummer, the trees are stripped bare.  The wind howls, driving a fine stinging snow through the nake branches.  Overhead, the sky is dark and ominous.  Jack stands, confused and shivering, realizing in his bewilderment that the girl is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lili...!  Princess Lili... Where are you...? There is no answer other than the hollow echo of his word lost on the wind.  It is bitterly cold.  Jack's wet hair freezes into strands of icicles.  He finds his clothing, wrapping himself in his fur vest.  His leafy cloak is inadequate for this weather and he hurries off, calling for the girl as he searches for shelter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lili... answer me... Lili...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The snowstorm has built-up into a full-scale blizzard. Jack staggers into the wind.  A large rock overhang provides shelter and Jack scrambles underneath. Jack scrapes together a small pile of twigs and leaves. Taking a flint and steel from his shoulder pouch, he starts busily striking sparks. A small fire burns vigorously under the overhang.  Jack warms himself and feeds sticks into the flames.  It grows darker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Princess Lili hides shivering behind the tree, watching Jack and his fire.  Her hands are out of sight, tucked in the folds of her gown for warmth.  Although she is cold and frightened she makes no move to expose herself or to join the Green Man under the overhand.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: Lili's lovely face contorts with sorrow.  A single tear starts in her eye and drops to her cheek, where it freeze like a diamond beauty-spot.  Lili reaches up to wipe away the frozen tear.  Her hand is horribly transformed. Coarse black hairs sprout along her wrist and down her slender fingers.  In place of delicately tapered nails grow wickedly curved claws.  It is a hand more animal tha human.  Lili regards it with disgust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Jack's small fire flickering faintly in the distance Princess Lili slinks away into the deep forest, eager to hide herself and her shame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack is sleeping.  He leans back against the rock wall, wrapped in his cloak.  The fire crackles brightly before him, casting animated shadows in all directions. A high-pitched, cackling LAUGH causes Jack to sit bolt- upright; wide-eyed and completely awake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What...?  Who's there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glowing like foxfire in the darkness, a semi-circle of luminous green eyes surrounds Jack's campfire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it?  Speak up. A second odd LAUGH is his only answer.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: is afraid.  He reaches into the folds of his cloak for hi knife, a small practical affair, hardly a weapon at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you...?  Answer me! Laughing still, a small man, an elf no more than knee-hig steps into the firelight.  He carries a tiny harp and a pair of pointed ears sprout from the wild tangle of his hair.  His bright clothing is everywhere tasseled and embroidered with flowers.  At first glance, it is hard to tell whether his face resembles a new-born babe or a wizened old man.  His name is HONEYTHORN GUMP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, Jack... think you be a Green Man and not know Gump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gump, is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye, Honeythorn Gump, come to serenade you, Jack... come to make you dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in no mood for dancing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, but you will be, Jack... Think you to sleep in a faerie ring and not spend the night a-dancing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faerie ring?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To be sure. Gump steps back and sweeps away the snow with his cap lik an over-zealous house porter.  A ring of red toadstools i revealed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lively reel twill warm your bones. Gump throws a handful of herbs onto the fire and the flames leap high, revealing the watchers whose eyes glowe in the dark.  Sitting in a semi-circle just outside the faerie ring are a number of foxes, wild goats, hares, weasels and badgers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here be your partners, Jack. Gump begins to strum a wild, haunting melody on his harp. The animals leap into the faerie ring, and linking paws, start a frantic circular dance around the bewildered Jack

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!  Tis not the time!  I want no part of your frolic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dance, Jack!  The night's but begun. Jack cannot resist.  He is drawn into the wild dance. Grabbing hold of a fox's paw, he joins the circle, leapin and cavorting to the maddening music. The tempo increases; the music growing ever-more manic as the crazed dancers whirl and caper.  Jack seems in a panic, dancing against his will, a prisoner of the frenzied harp-strumming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screaming)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it...!  No more... Gump pays no attention to his pleas, jumping wildly up an down as he flails at his harp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Round and round and round and round, Before you're lost ye most be found... Jack's face is a mask of agony; the dance pure hell.  Wit a supreme effort of will, he wrenches free from the fox's grasp and hurls himself to the ground by the fire.  The rhythm disrupted, the other animal dancers continue awkwardly as the music stops.  Gump is furious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how is it a mortal dare dictate to the faerie folk?  Is me music not to your liking?  Mayhap the dance of death by more your pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... I... I need to rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll have a long, long rest in the tomb, me lad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gasping)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I meant no disrespect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you now?  Well then, answer me this riddle and all be forgiven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if I cannot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, Jack, then tis your death song I'll be strumming. The animal dancers have stopped their frolic and stand solemnly watching the bewildered Green Man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ask away, and pray God my answer pleases thee. Gump grins maliciously and strums a melancholy chord on his harp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is a bell that does not ring, Yet, its knell makes the angels sing? Gump laughs, knowing full-well Jack can't solve his riddle.  Jack frowns in concentration, then breaks into a broad grin as the memory of Lili's song rushes back to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's bluebells!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The flower.  Bluebells.  To hear them ringing means your life's at an end. Gump hurls his harp to the ground and stomps on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damnation!  Codfish and cockles! Gammon and trotters!  You've bested me, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A riddle without an answer is but an empty cup when you're thirsty for wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleased with this)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well spoke.  True to the mark.  And if it's wine you're wanting, it's wine we shall have. Honeythorn Gump strides to the rear of the overhang, and brushing away the concealing cobwebs, ferns and moss, reveals a small wooden door built into the rock itself. Gump throws open the door and bows low for Jack to enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You be our guest, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (returning the bow)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm honored, Honeythorn Gump... but no more tricks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have me word, lad.  To answer a faerie riddle deserves as much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twas the Princess Lili gave me the answer... have you seen her, by chance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've laid eyes on no mortal but you this day, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I fear she's lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mayhap you be the one what's lost, and she safe by the castle hearth... but, come Jack, we'll warm your bones. Gump moves to the fire and pulls a burning brand from the flames.  As he does so, the animal dancers subtly shift and change, their forms dissolving like mist in the morning sun, transforming into faerie creatures.  The fox becomes a lithe, winged female wood nymph; the badger a squat goblin.  The other animals change into a variety of pixies, gnomes and brownies, all chattering and singing i an ancient, musical tongue. Gump leads the way through the door in the rock, followed by Jack and the teasing faeries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was a wee faerie lived under the hill, Hey, riddle-diddle and nickety-noo; And if he's nae gone he's living there still, Nickety, nackety, noo-noo-noo...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A narrow tunnel winds under the hill, twisting down between gnarled tree-roots and projecting splinters of ancient bone.  A rickety set of wooden steps has been built in this tunnel and Gump leads the precarious way down into the earth, holding his torch on high and singin for all his worth.  The other faeries tease Jack, jabbering and twitting and they pull his hair and tug at his clothing.  Jack does his best to ignore them, and at the same time, maintain a brave demeanor as he struggles for balance on the creaking stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The name of this faerie was Honeythorn Gump, Hey, riddle-diddle and nickety-noo; The sound of his harp made the mortals all jump, Nickety, nackety, noo-noo-noo. At the stroke of midnight, in the light of the moon, Hey, riddle-diddle and nickety-noo; All the faeries dance to Honeythorn's tune, Nickety-nackety, noo-noo-noo...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gump guides the procession in to a vast underground hall, hung with fine tapestries and filled with all manner of odd and ancient wonders:  Roman armor, bits of mosaics an marble statuary, etc.  A long wooden trestle table stretches down the center of the hall, set with burning candles, bowls of fruit and nuts, golden goblets of every shape and size. Gump tosses his torch into an open, glowing fire-pit, the smoke drifting up to the shrouded tree-roots above.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we be.  And fit for a king if I say so meself. Jack is properly awed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tis splendid.  I feel I must be dreaming. This delights the faeries, who twitter with laughter as they buzz around Jack, guiding him to the carved High Sea at the head of the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed, me lad.  And if life is a dream, better you dread the waking. Several rows of wine casks are ranked against one wall. Gump seizes a large flagon from the table and fills it with sparkling elderberry wine. Jack sits somewhat uncomfortably in the High Seat with it ornately carved dragons and basalisks entwined about him. The beautiful wood nymph hovers by his side, smiling and whispering in his ear. Gump fills Jack's goblet from the flagon and sets about filling the others in turn down the table.  Jack is embarrassed by the wood nymph's obvious attentions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make her stop it, will you Gump... please! Gump snorts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, Jack-lad, she likes you, is all.  And what hot-blooded hero wouldn't welcome the affections of a fair nymph like Oona here...?  If your blood runs so cold, boy, you be a corpse before your time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does she want from me? OONA, the wood-nymph giggles wildly and covers Jack's cheek with kisses as she hovers at his side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fool question, lad.  Drink up and warm your blood.  You'll find the answer at the bottom of your cup. Gump motions with his flagon for Jack to drink, but the Green Man merely lifts his goblet and stares dolefully at the contents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elderberry wine.  No finer drink under heaven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks... er, delicious... (sniffing his cup)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Such a fine bouquet... very aromatic...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are ye afraid of me wine?  Did your momma tell ye never to take food nor drink from the Wee Folk?  Think if ye sup with the faeries you'll be enchanted?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... I... I don't want to be rude, but... it's generally known that --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Generally known!  What general ever knew more than to lace up his boots?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't misunderstand.  I am grateful for your hospitality and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is afraid of enchantment!  Will you listen to the fool prattle on. All the faeries and goblins burst into raucous laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here the world is turned upside- down; precious summertime frozen into a wintry memory; the underworld unleashed and all spirits walk the earth at will... this be the state of things and the blamed fool won't take a sip of wine for fear of enchantment! Jack swallows his fear.  He stares heard into his cup and in a single decisive moment, drains it to the bottom.  Th faeries all clap and cheer.  Oona gives him a big hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But... but, why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big question that, lad.  Why what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why has this happened to the world? Why is it winter now, and dark?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye.  Honeythorn Gump'd be a powerful wizard indeed could he answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're looking for enchantment, Jack, that I can give thee... Gump screws up his face with concentration and gestures with his emerald ring.  All at once, the carved dragons and serpents on Jack's chair seem to come alive.  They writhe out of the woodwork, sinuous and evil.  Jack is terrified as they wrap about him, pinning his arms and chest to the chair as Oona and the other faeries laugh with malicious glee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...!  Stop it now... please! Gump snaps his fingers and the chair is but a chair again the carved snakes mere decorations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That much magic I can offer ye, a small measure of entertainment at best.  Making the world a frozen hell is beyond me modest powers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, what's gone wrong?  Why did it happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If ye want more tricks, I'm your man, but for big questions ye must go elsewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you care about what's happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Course we care.  What good's the world locked in a season of death. Frozen up, no folks to scare out of their wits on a summer's night; no babies to tickle; no more spells to cast... Think that's an enjoyable prospect?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There must be an answer somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: True... But it won't come easy or free.  If ye want to ask, ask Jenny Greenteeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny Greenteeth?  Who's she? At the mention of the feared name, all the faeries jabber and chatter frantically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone worthy of respect, lad.  She be a water spirit, lives in a bog down at sea-side.  Hideous creature to look at, even by my doubtful standards; devours little children, she does, when she can catch them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is it this hag knows the truth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think there be truth only in beauty, lad?  If you've the courage to ask and take care to avoid her terrible claws, Jenny Greenteeth has the answers you seek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you lead me to her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye.  On the morrow we go, but tonight... (he lifts his flagon high)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... tonight is for making merry. Gump drinks the flagon down.  The other faeries and Jack join in the festivities, lifting their goblets in a single, raucous toast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is shortly after dawn, but the feeble winter sun provides little warmth or light.  The gray day has the appearance of perpetual twilight.  From the rear, we easily recognize Princess Lili as she moves toward the frozen stream.  Her fine embroidered dress is soiled and torn, her long, unbound hair matted and stuck with burrs and twigs.  She's had a rough night in the open.  At the stream's edge she kneels, her back still to the CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: THE FROZEN STREAM
dialogues.text: Lili's furred, claw-like hand reaches out and wipes a covering of snow from the ice.  The frozen surface of the stream provides an uneven mirror which makes the reflection of Lili's face appear even more monstrous.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: The distant SOUND of LAUGHTER and SINGING, causes Lili to look up from the ice.  Her face is hideously transformed. Sharp fangs jut out over her lower lip.  Her nostrils are wide and flaring.  Patches of hair sprout on her cheeks. Her ears are pointed. She reacts to the strange sound like an animal, sniffing the air.  And, like an animal, she stealthily creeps off, ducking between the frozen trees like a carnivore stalkin her prey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SOUNDS of SINGING grow nearer as Lili creeps through the woods, hiding herself behind the trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out of the marsh, the troop of elves and faeries is led b Gump and Jack.  The procession shimmers and sparkles, and Lili shrinks back from the joyous proceedings, hiding herself in shame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The severed head of the stallion unicorn lies, half- buried, in the muck.  A croaking raven perches on the small stump of horn remaining, probing his beak into the hollow eye-socket.  At the sound of the faeries' MUSICAL approach, the bird spreads his wings and flies off.

dialogues.speaker: THE FAERIES
dialogues.text: Jack and the faeries hurry to the spot where the dead unicorn lies.  They body is stretched out several yards away from the severed head.  No one speaks.  The awesome spectacle silences the procession's glad singing.  Even some of the magic sparkle seems to have left the faeries as they stand, grouped like mourners, around the dead unicorn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sadly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mortals at their foolish pleasure, Rob the Earth of all her treasure... Jack kneels beside the dead unicorn, dumb with sorrow.  H runs has hand along the hollow flank of the fallen animal One of the evil Baron's barbed bolts stands straight out of the unicorn's neck and Jack yanks it free with a sudde pull.  He is about to hurl the weapon far out into the swamp when he thinks better of it and pushes the bolt int his belt. Gump silently motions with his head and starts away from the unicorn's body.  The other faeries follow dejectedly. Jack is the last to leave, staring down at the mutilated animal as the anger inside builds to a fury.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fearful slimy place.  The roots of a rotted oak twist down into the murky water like dead men's fingers.  A fou green slime floats on the surface.  Several splintered bones protrude from the mud at the water's edge. Gump and the faeries stop a good ways off.  They can feel the potent evil of the spot and dread it.  Any semblance of joy has left them.  Gump's demeanor is as dour and severe as a schoolmaster's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye. (pointing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That foul wallow be where Jenny Greenteeth dwells.  Oona... lure her out.  Play the part of a girl-child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't get caught, that's what! She'll suck your bones like honey- comb. Gump reaches into his jerkin and produces a small ivory- mounted hand-mirror.  He gives this to Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here now.  Toss her this when you've the chance.  Jenny Greenteeth can't resist the sight of herself in a glass.  She's terribly vain.  Praise her beauty and you'll lull her sweet as a babe in a cradle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not so sure)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if she thinks me a liar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fie on what she thinks!  You mind her claws and teeth... Cast your spell, Oona. At Gump's command, the faerie Oona begins to spin.  She twirls into an iridescent blur, surrounding herself with a cocoon of light, and when she slows, she has metamorphosed into the image of a four-year old girl with pink cheeks and golden ringlets. Skipping and singing, the transformed Oona makes her way around the edge of the bog.  Jack follows, somewhat unsurely, at a safe distance. The apparition of the little girl kneels by the bank. There is a slight disturbance on the scummy surface of th water, as if a sudden, localized wind had sprung up.  All at once, like a serpent rising from the depths, a bony, mottled-green arm thrusts up through the slime, the clawe fingers clutching for the child. Even as the fierce talons close on their prey, the "child is gone in a dazzle of light and the winged, laughing Oon hovers high above the bog, looking down on the fearsome and outraged JENNY GREENTEETH. The water hag is the color of a decomposing corpse.  And like a corpse, her ragged flesh and hair seem to be peeling in tatters from the emaciated body.  Her nose has caved in, and her rotted lips betray a mouthful of fearsome fangs.  She is furious at having been tricked an rails at Oona.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (raging)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rat-spittle and toad-breath! Damned, accursed cross twixt a she- bat and a bullfrog!  How dare you use Jenny Greenteeth so? Jack takes advantage of the hag's distracted fury to rush up and toss the hand mirror in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive us... er, fair one, we wanted only to bring a gift. Jenny seizes the mirror as eagerly as if it were food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bring you the only treasure worthy of your loveliness... for naught else in the universe rivals the reflected glory of your beauty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well spoke, boy.  You have discerning taste for one so young... Just who might you be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They call me Green Jack, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come closer then, Jack, that I might give you proper thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your fair smile be thanks enough. Better I stand afar to admire your beauty complete. Jenny Greenteeth cannot resist the mirror and preens before it in a hideous parody of a young woman at her toilette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think me fair, do you, Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moon herself would hide behind a cloud rather than dare comparison with you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moon is too round of face, methinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sight of you makes flowers seem like dross.  All the heavenly angels must envy your grace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like well your conceit, Jack.  Tis rare to find an honest lad in this troubled world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye.  And it is the trouble befallen us that brings me here.  I entreat you to tell me the cause of our surrounding sorrow, most lovely of the lovely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear lad, what does winter bespeak but death?  It is a time of mourning.  This calamity is a curse. Something wondrous and beautiful has been taken from the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A unicorn's been slain.  The last stallion in all the country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why then, there thou hast.  We be lucky worse has not befallen us. Jack pulls the Baron's crossbow bolt from his belt to sho to Jenny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here be the death weapon; the unicorn's blood dry upon it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couer de Noir!  A demon if the Devil ever made one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He chopped off the horn and left the rest to rot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be the Baron's way. There'll be no light or life in the world until the alicorn is taken from him and he vanquished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do I get the horn back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll need the fastest steed alive, for Couer de Noir's castle rests at the very edge of the earth.  Only the sharpest sword and the golden armor of Achilles will protect you from his fury.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do I find the Baron's castle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Follow the raven in her flight, Follow old black wing to the edge of night...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not very precise directions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come sit beside me, sweet boy, and I'll draw you a map.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nay.  Tempting as your invitation be.  Tell me one thing more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ask away, sweet man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What became of the princess?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (miffed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Princess?  I know of no princess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Princess Lili, Godwin's daughter. She was with me when calamity struck, but after I could find no trace of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is she fair, this princess?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exceeding fair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angry and jealous)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As fair as me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twould be to compare one star with another in the summer sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's dead!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dead, dead, dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Far as you're concerned she's dead, believe it or not. Jack is deeply struck by this disclosure even though he doubts it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is sad news, be it true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be sad, Jack, not with me here to give you cheer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tis not the time to speak of cheer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll visit again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sadly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a hummingbird returns to the fairest blossom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a sigh)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a fine meal you'd make, be the rest of you sweet as your tongue. Jenny Greenteeth slips abruptly under the foul surface of her bog hole.  Jack returns to Gump and the other faeries

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The princess is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lamentable news, Jack... but tis the fate of the living concerns us now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you hear?  Twas the killing of the unicorn caused it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye.  Black Baron's mischief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the horn be restored the curse is ended.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time for a champion.  Can you do more than pick acorns and rob bird's nests, Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll do what I have to do, for Princess Lili's sake!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (clapping Jack on the back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bravely spoke.  You've the heart of a champion, true enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twill take more than heart.  Where do we find the armor of Achilles, for a start?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know where to find it.  Taking possession be another matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lindfarne Mound, an ancient tumulus, covers almost an acre and rises, domed and treeless under a sullen sky. Wispy smoke curls from the top of the mound.  A pair of black ravens circles overhead. The rag-tag procession of elves and faeries appears cautiously from out of the frozen forest and stands gazing, somewhat apprehensively, at the distant tumulus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There it be, lad.  The Lindfarne Mound.  Kings long forgotten lie there, lost in their final sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have we turned grave-robber, then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tomb it once was, boy, and a tomb it may yet be... There's another in residence at Lindfarne now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who might that be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No less a creature than the Lindfarne Worm. At the mention of the dread name, Oona and the other faeries cringe and chatter fearfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I'm to be a dragon-slayer, is that it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Jack-lad, no one's asking ye to skewer the worm.  Even St. Michael'd have a job on his hands for all that.  But the serpent hoards a pile of booty, Achilles' armor among his treasures... if we find our way within the mound and him asleep...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knaves and robbers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The faeries gather around a circular opening atop the tumulus.  Quantities of smoke issue from the interior. Gump ties one end of a coiled rope to a large stone.  The other end is lowered into the mound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better pray the worm's a sound sleeper, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do the praying.  I've work ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's the spirit, lad.  If ye run into trouble, give a yank here and we'll haul ye up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's left of me... How do I recognize the armor of Achilles?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll know it when you see it... tis a splendid sight, all covered with gold... Don't fear making noise.  Dragons be deaf as tree stumps. Jack takes hold of the rope and lowers himself into the smoking hole.  Oona flutters over and kisses him on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Courage, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blushing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I pray God grants it me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No need.  There be no more potent charm than a faerie's love. Embarrassed, Jack slides from sight into the hole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tomb is vast, like the arched dome of a cathedral. The curving sides are built from exquisitely fitted block of stone, moss-covered and dripping moisture. Suspended like a dangling spider on his filament, Jack slides down the rope into the drifting smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Far below, the floor of the tomb is everywhere heaped wit treasure.  Great stacks of gold plate gleam in the half- light; mounds of gem-stones sparkle.  The treasure of the faeries is a trash-pile compared with this hoard. In the midst of the splendor, the DRAGON lies sleeping, surrounded by clouds of smoke.  With its horned, whiskere head and reversed, golden scales, the beast greatly resembles the symbol used in the Chinese zodiac.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack comes to the end of his rope and drops into the treasure with a loud CRASH.  The CLATTER is alarming and Jack dives for cover behind a chest brimming with rubies. The dragon has not heard a thing and continues to snore, belching smoke like a miniature volcano. Cautiously, Jack begins his search.  It's a bit bewildering as there is such a quantity of wealth. Everywhere he looks more remarkable treasure is revealed. Casks of jewels, weapons worked in gold and silver, golde plates and goblets, ropes of pearls in snake-like coils. There is armor of all description, from the breastplates of ancient Rome to the winged helmets of Viking marauders Jack is puzzled by mysterious Japanese samurai armor and amazed by the heft and weight of a huge Arabian scimitar. Search as he will, Jack can find no sign of the armor of Achilles.  He burrows under mounds of gems and opens a sequence of treasure chests, discovering only more gems and yet again more treasure. The dragon MOANS unexpectedly in his sleep, causing Jack to make a terrifying discovery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sleeping dragon looms larger than a house.  Smoke coils above his massive head.  One scaled forelimb is extended, gleaming talons hooked like scythe blades. Gripped in the evil claw something extraordinary glitters Wrought from pure gold and embossed with ancient and beautiful designs:  it is the breastplate of Achilles.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: approaches the sleeping monster, like a mouse creeping up on a snoring cat.  But, the beauty of the golden breastplate calms him.  The legendary armor is so wondrously made that Jack can only gaze upon it with awe. A fiery snort from the dragon brings him back to his senses.  There's work to be done.  With all the delicacy he can muster, Jack takes hold of the breastplate and tries to pry it from the dragon's grip.  It's not easy. The giant serpent is fitful and groans in his sleep, grasping the armor all the tighter. Jack tugs at the breastplate with all his might and suddenly, it comes free, sending Jack tumbling over backwards.  The NOISE is deafening, but it is not the sound that wakes the dragon. The mighty talons clench, disturbed by the missing armor. A single green eye, large as a dinner-plate, slides open. The whiskered mouth widens, belching fire and smoke. Enraged, the dragon rears up, venting its spleen in a torrent of unrecognizable words.  The mysterious language sounds somehow Oriental, perhaps Japanese or Chinese. Jack cowers in terror, trying to dig himself into the hea of jewels like a mole scratching for cover.  The dragon spots him instantly.  Addressing Jack in English, he sounds like a sing-song Confucius, a Grade-B Fu Manchu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you do, boy?  You be velly solly, come here intellupt my sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (terrified)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know... I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  Speakee loud!  No hear velly good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said, I mean no harm... I thought this as empty tomb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You come stealee tleasoo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no, never... nothing like that... never crossed my mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No need lie, boy.  I no hurt you. Do I look like I wanna hurt you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, er... no.  I mean, you don't look like dragons I've heard of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Course not.  I no flum here.  I come flum Cathay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Country fa' fa' away.  To the East, beyond the lising sun...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: East of Mercia?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got no idee.  People there lookee diffelent; speakee diffelent. Nothing the same.  In my countlee I bling good luck.  Makee lain and thunder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't ravage the countryside, devouring maidens and burning the crops?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dlagon not like that.  Dlagon is spilit of life... spilit of stlength and goodness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you'll understand my quest.  An ogre named Blackheart has killed the last stag unicorn and stolen his horn.  The world outside is cursed, plunged into eternal winter.  Unless I return the alicorn, the earth will be frozen forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flozen foleva not good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's terrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An' how you do it?  How you rift cuss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need your help.  In order to fight Blackheart, I must wear the armor of Achilles.  I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (roaring)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You come stealee tleasoo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no... Don't you understand? The dragon roars and swells.  Flames issue from his gapin mouth and an iridescent light shimmers along his scales as his form suddenly alters and shifts, transforming from the benevolent Eastern dragon to the more familiar winged monster of Western folklore.  When he speaks now, all trace of accent is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stupid, puny mortal!  Do you think I suffer pilfering gladly? The dragon belches a sheet of flame straight at Jack, who rolls aside just in time, but not quickly enough to keep his clothing from being singed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, wait... please... listen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No more listening!  Your time is at an end, insignificant whelp! The dragon slashes at Jack with his fearsome claws, batting away the breastplate held before him as protection.  Jack jumps back, hurling a helmet at the dragon.  It bounces harmlessly off the gleaming scales.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pray to whatever worthless god you revere!  You're no more than meat to me now. Jack scrambles frantically through the piles of loot, ducking behind chests of gold as the dragon stalks him in the shadows.  In his frenzied flight, his groping hand chances upon an ivory bow and a quiver of silver arrows. The dragon rears up on his hind-quarters, lashing his terrible tail, towering above Jack. Quickly, the Green Man notches an arrow and lets it fly a the dragon's throat.  It bounces harmlessly off the glistening scales.  Jack fires a second, and a third. Both arrows are easily deflected and fall clattering back into the treasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are those gnats come to trouble me? Methinks this pesky gadfly needs swatting. The dragon leaps for Jack like a tiger pouncing on his prey, but somehow the nimble boy eludes his pursuer, diving headlong under a golden chariot.  Furious, the dragon crashes about, flipping over anything in his path as he searches for Jack.

dialogues.speaker: THE ROPE FROM ABOVE
dialogues.text: Honeythorn Gump hangs from the dangling rope like a monkey, observing the mayhem below.  Oona hovers at his side, her transparent dragonfly wings a-blur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mind them claws, Jack.  Stay out of his way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh dear... oh dear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From above, the dragon's search for Jack resembles a raccoon flipping over rocks in a streambed hunt for crayfish.  A large pile of silver and gold shields is stacked like roof-tiles and the dragon tosses them aside looking for Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep one jump ahead, lad.  Don't waste time looking back.

dialogues.speaker: JACK AND THE DRAGON
dialogues.text: The dragon wrenches away a suit of jeweled armor and discovers Jack cowering underneath.  A lungfull of fire sets Jack's clothing aflame as he scurries out of the way There is no other place to hide.  Jack is trapped, his back up against a massive shield.  Enraged, the dragon rears above him, poised for the kill. The dark shadow of doom falls across Jack as he cowers helplessly.

dialogues.speaker: GUMP
dialogues.text: Running with the rope, Gump pendulums into the air, swinging back and forth across the interior of the mound. Snatching up a jeweled war-club, he swings past the dragon's head, belaboring him with the mace as he passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Filthy worm!  Have a taste o' that! Furious and distracted, the raging dragon turns his attentions to this new annoyance, swatting out with his talons as Gump swings by him.  Oona buzzes round and roun his smoking, fearsome head, staying just out of reach as the dragon slashes at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leg it, Jack!  Move lad, while there's time.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: As his companions occupy the dragon's attention, Jack crawls away on his hands and knees, searching for a new hiding place.  Sticking straight out of the heaped treasure before him, a splendid sword-hilt catches his eye.  It seems to glow with some inner force.  The golden pommel gleams. Jack grasps the sword with both hands, rising to his feet as he draws it from the pile of jewels.  The blade is nea long as he is, awesome and shining with its own special light.  Jack holds it in front of him like a crucifier in a religious procession.  The light from the blade shines on his face, imbuing his spirit with courage and resolution. Gump and Oona continue to annoy the dragon, swinging around his head and taunting him with the insignificant blows.  The dragon lashes out at them, ignoring Jack. Jack swings the mighty, shining sword back over his shoulder and rushes forward, a fierce WAR-CRY issuing fro his snarling mouth.  With one mighty swing, like a woodsman chopping an oak, he strikes at the dragon's hind leg, severing it at the joint. The dragon's WAIL of pain is abrupt and piercing.  Blood fountains from the amputated limb as the giant serpent sways for balance. The dragon falls forward, toppling like a felled tree directly toward Jack.  The Green Man stands his ground, holding his gleaming sword above his head with both hands The dragon impales himself on the tip, driving the keen blade deep into his breast as he crashes to the ground. The sword is wrenched from Jack's hand and he jumps clear the dragon writhing on his back in his death throes. The mighty tail continues to lash about, wreaking havoc among the treasure.  Jack nimbly avoids the random slashing and leaps up onto the dragon's scaled stomach. With a mighty tug, he draws his sword from the beast's chest.  A geyser of steaming blood follows the blade. The talons on the dragon's forelegs grasp and clench spasmodically but Jack ducks between them, avoiding the terrible claws.  With a single backhand swing, he lops th dragon's snarling head from his neck.  Copious quantities of boiling blood flush across the spread jewels. Jack lifts his sword above his head and lets out an exultant victory CRY.  Above him, Gump and Oona CHEER, shouting "Bravo" and "hooray!" The dragon's head lies in a pool of blood, the forked tongue still probing the air.  The great green eye slides closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young hare sits timidly in the sear grass, ears twitching, his large frightened eyes blink.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: Several yards from the crouching rabbit, the Princess Lil stalks through the tall grass.  We do not SEE her face, but her embroidered gown hangs in tattered rags about her She moves with great stealth, like an animal, drawing ever-closer to the rabbit.  Her limbs are completely covered by a shaggy fleece of dark hair. The rabbit is very close now.  Lili's movements are like cat's as she creeps closer and closer.  All at once, in a sudden, wild movement, the girl leaps from the concealing grass and pounces on the unsuspecting hare, killing it in an instant.

dialogues.speaker: C.U. LILI
dialogues.text: We SEE the Princess's face for the first time now as she tears at the dead rabbit with her teeth.  Fangs actually, for Lili's features are now far more animal than human. Her eyes gleam ferociously and blood smears her whiskered mouth as she eagerly devours her kill.

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK
dialogues.text: to SEE Lili's hunkering form, totally bestial in its spread-leg attitude.  The tattered dress seems merely a ludicrous refinement on so savage a creature.  Her nails have lengthened into claws and she makes small animal noises as she tears at the rabbit's flesh. The SHADOW of a mounted rider falls across her form and she looks up, cat eyes widening in terror at what she sees.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: The Black Baron sits on his dark charger, staring down at the cowering girl.  He laughs dryly under his horned wolf mask, the black cloak whipping about him in the wind.  At his side is a deadly rapier fashioned from the long twisting ivory length of the alicorn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A child of nature... How delightful.

dialogues.speaker: LILI'S FLIGHT
dialogues.text: Terrified, Lili drops what's left of the rabbit and sprints for the woods.  She is very agile, running freely like a feral cat.  The Baron watches for a moment, then digs his spurs into his horse's flank and is after her. Lili runs for all she's worth, darting and zig-zagging in a frantic effort to avoid capture.  For all her speed and agility she can't outrun a horse, and in moments the Baro bears down upon her, reaching low to catch the back of he torn dress and swing her up in front of him on the saddle

dialogues.speaker: BARON AND LILI
dialogues.text: Lili claws and scratches, ripping at the Baron as she fights to be free.  Her efforts only elicit laughter from her captor as he easily pins her struggling arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like your spirit.  I like things wild and free.  More of a challenge... Don't worry, my pet, I'll soon have you housebroke. Laughing his evil laugh, the Baron clutches the strugglin animal/girl tightly to his chest and gallops away into th frozen woods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the faeries have gathered for a great feast.  The dragon's severed head is set upright on a pike.  Haunches of spitted dragon meat turn slowly over a bed of coals. Much of the treasure has been gathered into sacks and stands by the rope like harvest grain awaiting transport. Several gnomes and elves are busy hoisting the sacks up out of the mound.  Jack and the other faeries sit on the dragon's carcass, feasting and swilling wine from golden goblets.  Jack wears the armor of Achilles and in it he i transformed from a wild hermit to a valiant knight.  The others wear bits and pieces of bejeweled armor plucked from the treasure hoard.  Gump has on a horned Viking helmet which fits him badly.  Another imp, a monkey-faced elf named SCREWBALL, wears the helm of a Roman legionnaire.  Everyone is singing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dragon's breath is made of fire, His heart be black with sin, sin, sin. But, his meat's as sweet as any desire, After you've lifted his skin, skin, skin... The faeries laugh and cavort.  Gump waves a sizzling lump of dragon meat in the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There be no finer victuals than worm flesh, lad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better we eat him than the other way round.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep me belly full, Jack.  Kill us another worm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hush up, Screwball.  Do your own worm-sticking if you like the taste so well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nay.  Jack's the dragon-slayer, ain't you, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the grace of God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No false modesty, lad.  You're a proper champion.  Achilles' armor sits on you like it was forged to fit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the sword... surely that was providence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't come no sharper. Jack lifts the incredible sword, studying its length before laying it against the fallen dragon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe this is a sword such as the archangels wield.  Surely St. Michael had so fine a blade when he drove the serpent from heaven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then, you've got the sword and you've got the armor; all's lacking is the steed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fastest in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know where to find him... He lies out on the marsh, raven-fodder; his horn torn from his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: True, lad, the stallion's gone, but the mare still lives. Jack smiles:  this is a happy truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She be fastest now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you find her, Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know where to look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An isolated glade deep in the frozen forest.  Icicles han like frozen daggers from the surrounding trees.  A light dusting of snow powders the ground.  No birds sing.  All is silent and still. Jack, Gump, Screwball and Oona creep through the ice- coated underbrush.  Screwball is clumsy and crashes over several gelid ferns which break like shattering crystal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhhh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Screwball!  You dolt!  I've a mind to change you into a toad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's already half toad, if you ask me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not the time for squabbling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
