dialogues.text: Sorry. The foursome, all clad in armor, continue silently to the edge of the glade.  They conceal themselves behind the trunk of a huge, gnarled oak.  The glade is empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do we do now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We wait. Disgruntled, the faeries settle down to wait.  Jack removes his helmet and rests against the treetrunk.  Oona nestles by his side, tittering softly and tickling his neck.  Jack does his best to ignore her.  Oona grows more playful, whispering and giggling at Jack's annoyance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhhh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something's coming. Indeed, an animal can clearly be heard approaching the glade; a crunch of footfalls on the frozen ground and the icy crack of branches snapping.  Jack and his companions peer around the tree trunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shaft of pale sunlight pierces through the cloud-cover and angles down into the glade at the moment the mare unicorn steps out of the underbrush.  The light glows on her milk-white hide and her rounded, swollen flanks. Slowly, with modesty and a certain dignified stride, the mare moves to the center of the glade and settles herself down, drawing her legs beneath her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's she doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think she's about to foal.

dialogues.speaker: JACK AND THE FAERIES
dialogues.text: as they stare in awe at the resting unicorn.  Even the demented Screwball has a silly smile on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pregnant, is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would appear so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How wonderful. They are suddenly interrupted by the LOUD HOWLING of wolves.  The plaintive WAIL stabs through the cold air like a cry from Hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wolves!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They want the mare. Jack draws his gleaming sword.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Careful, lad. The wolves' HOWLING grows LOUDER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evil brutes.  Shant work their mischief here.

dialogues.speaker: GLADE
dialogues.text: Sword in hand, Jack steps out into the clearing.  The mar unicorn is startled by his sudden appearance but makes no effort to rise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right, girl.  I won't hurt you. The unicorn is soothed by Jack's words and seems to recognize him. Jack places the tip of his sword on the ground and stands waiting, hands folded on the pommel, patient as a statue. Ghostlike in their silent stealth, the wolves materialize along the edge of the glade.  Large and gray, their amber eyes glowing, the wolves begin to circle, moving closer t their prey.  Jack readies himself, holding his sword in both hands. With his tail curled high, the leader of the pack snarls and rushes for the mare.  Jack cuts him off, sending him flying with a swift sword stroke. The leader's charge provokes an all-out attack.  The wolves close in HOWLING from all sides.  Jack wields his great sword like a berserk, chopping and slashing, drivin the furious wolves away from the mare.  Busy fighting three of the brutes, he doesn't notice the wounded leader creeping behind him. The leader springs, jumping on Jack's back, tearing at hi neck with his fangs.

dialogues.speaker: SCREWBALL IN TREETOP
dialogues.text: Screwball has climbed one of the surrounding trees, bringing his bow and arrows with him.  He SEES the wolf attacking Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steady, Jack. Screwball draws his bow, aims quickly, and shoots.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: is powerless against the huge wolf mauling him from behind.  Only the golden armor he wears protects him from the terrible claws.  Screwball's arrow finds its mark, straight between the animal's shoulder blades.  The wolf cries out once and drops lifeless from Jack's back. Jack waves gratefully at the faerie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in your debt, Screwball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch behind or I'll never collect on it! Jack spins about in time to see the leader's mate charge savagely.  The wolf leaps, a high, acrobatic arc whose trajectory moves from a blur of gray fur to the precise delineation of cold yellow eyes, lolling tongue and wicked, gleaming fangs. Jack lifts his sword as the wolf lands on his shoulders and chest.  Falling backwards, Jack thrusts up and the ti on his blade impales the wolf as they drop to the ground. Tossing the squirming animal as a farmer would a fork-loa of hay, Jack flips the wolf over his head.  Scrambling to his knees, he delivers the death-stroke with swift efficiency. Standing over the dead wolves, sword in hand, his breastplate drenched in their blood, Jack is terrible to behold.  The others in the pack sense they have been beaten and slink whimpering back into the woods, tails abjectly hooked between their legs. Gump, Screwball and Oona dart from their hiding places. They jump and leap about Jack, chattering happily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well done, lad.  Stout heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wolf-slayer, worm-sticker... give a cheer for the champion!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were I a mortal girl, Jack, methinks I'd be in love with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I'd kiss you without turning my garments inside-out and sewing bells all over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No need for bells, Jack.  I'll nay enchant ye. Oona stops her teasing and points to the unicorn, a look of utter wonder replacing the mischief on her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, look!

dialogues.speaker: THE UNICORN
dialogues.text: A baby unicorn has been born; coal black with the first stump of a horn showing on his forehead.  The foal lies beside his mother, who licks the blood from his shining, moist coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't he beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: FAERIES AND UNICORN
dialogues.text: Jack and the faeries move closer to the unicorn.  There i something holy about the scene, like an Adoration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wee stallion. Jack drops to his knees before the mare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Praise be to God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Small miracles better than no miracles...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Such a sad world, be there no unicorns to brighten it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No fear of that now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye.  This wee stud'll beget a line of champions. The faeries kneel with Jack before the unicorn and her foal.  The mare regards them without fear, recognizing friends.  Stretching out her neck to Jack, she allows him to pet her and scratch behind her ears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're shy and pretty, little mother... You deserve a pretty name... I'll call you Sapphire, for your eyes shine so...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SOUND of swords clashing and the SHOUTING of tiny voices CARRIES OVER to the faeries' make-shift military camp.  Colorful tents stand under frozen trees, pennants snapping in the icy wind.  A small army of elves, imps, goblins, gnomes and faeries has gathered, all decked out in various odd bits of armor recovered from the dragon's lair.  Groups of these tiny folk are engaged in martial training, practicing with swords, lances and bows. As we MOVE through the camp amid this mock mayhem, certai isolated incidents attract our attention: Two goblins duel furiously, sweating and panting under th weight of their ill-matched armor.  They are clearly exhausted.  As the other elves continue slashing at one another, these two take time out; one leaning against a tree trunk while the other folds his arms in repose.  But their swords CONTINUE to duel, alone in mid-air, the blades crashing together MAGICALLY like iron birds. Another group practices archery, aiming their tiny arrows at a straw scarecrow some distance away.  They are extremely accurate, puncturing the dummy in a dozen vital spots.  When the last arrow strikes, instead of retrievin them, the faeries stand their ground.  One-by-one, the arrows PULL FREE from the scarecrow and FLY back unaided through the air to land safely in their owner's quivers. Two huge knights, each over seven feet, slug it out in full armor with battle axes.  They bash away at one- another, until a fearsome blow literally cuts one in half The upper portion of the bisected knight topples to the ground with a LOUD CLANG.  The two armored legs remain erect, swaying slightly like trees in the wind.  Suddenly a tiny head appears above the left cuisse.  It is an elf. He is LAUGHING.  Another elf pops his head out of the right-hand cuisse and the two "legs" hop off in opposite directions. The fallen armor also comes apart:  one gnome in the breastplate; another lifting the helm from the gorget. The victorious "knight" likewise begins to disassemble, revealing a number of LAUGHING elves within, like clowns performing a carnival prank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack surveys his elfin army from the crest of the hill. He is mounted bareback on Sapphire, the mare unicorn, and rides easily without reins or bridle.  The tiny black foa trots alongside his mother, and beside it pants an angry Gump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't see why I can't ride, too! I'm second in command, damn it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The colt's still too small.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm small... and I can make myself smaller still... Small as a bee! Small as dust...!  Want to see me do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've no time for tricks this day, Honeythorn Gump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tricks, is it?  Why I'll trick ye! Ungrateful whelp!  I'll sour your milk and bird droppings'll fall from the sky wherever ye walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Save your mischief for the Black Baron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye!  That too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll need more than bird droppings for Blackheart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll drop a cow on the knave!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drop a mountain on him and we won't need our troops. They laugh together, feeling confident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine-looking army.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We march on Castle Couer de Noir within the hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you plan on finding this here castle, if ye don't mind me asking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A true and troubling question, Gump... We'll start from where the unicorn was killed.  The Baron must have left a trail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Track the demon to his lair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye.  And hang his foul hide up like dirty laundry for the drying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rag-tag army of faeries on the march.  Jack rides at the head of the column on Sapphire.  Gump has had his way and is mounted on the colt, who trots obediently by his mother's side.  The other elves and faeries are either on foot or mounted on an odd array of wild animals.  Deer, foxes, rabbits, each serves as a steed for a tiny warrior Bright banners undulate from numbers of lance tips.  A variety of armor glistens in the pale wintry sun. Overhead, Oona and several other small nymphs ride on flying songbirds. As they march and ride, all the faerie folk are singing, their voices high and clear, shimmering like wind over a moonlit lake; precise as birdsong; haunting as an echo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sky is high, the world is wide, Beneath the flowers faeries hide. The ocean's deep, the moon's asleep; In Oberon's care our souls will keep. The stars are cold, the Gods are old, Our heroes all be brave and bold. The Devil's sly, the end is nigh, Wicked ogres too must die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SINGING CARRIES OVER as the faeries move out of the woods onto the frozen estuary.  Jack urges the mare unicorn ahead of the procession.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trees are green; spirits unseen, The world we know is but a dream...

dialogues.speaker: THE DEAD UNICORN
dialogues.text: Jack rides Sapphire near where the body of her mate lies decomposing.  As before, a black raven perches on the stallion's skull.  The bird emits a vile CROAK as Jack approaches. Alarmed by the raven and the sight of her dead mate, the unicorn rears on her hind legs.  Jack clings to the animal's mane.  The raven CROAKS.

dialogues.speaker: C.U. RAVEN
dialogues.text: The large bird spreads his wings, RASPING and CROAKING at the rearing unicorn and rider.  For a single, horrifying moment, the raven appears to alter and change, transmutin into a HARPY.  In place of the bird's head and bill is a visage resembling both skull and snake.  Talons appear to be gnarled feet and a pair of distinctly human breasts sprout from between the sooty feathers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beware... beware... The harpy takes wing, CROAKING.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: struggles to control the frantic unicorn.  Gump and the other faeries ride up as Jack quiets the animal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trouble, Jack? Jack points at the raven flying high over the treetops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must follow that bird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny Greenteeth said:  "Follow the raven in her flight..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye.  Said to follow it to the edge of night.  But is this the right bird?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure.  It spoke to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Birds speak to me all the time. What did it say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beware.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like the bird we want. (calling to troops)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right lads, follow yon raven! The troop of faeries shout and laugh, eagerly pursing the raven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The faerie troop rides to the edge of the wintry forest. Their spirits are still high, but something about the moo of the place takes hold.  The singing stops.  Bright laughter fades. Screwball, a WORRIED ELF and a NERVOUS GOBLIN ride side- by-side into the frightening forest.  They make an odd trio, mounted as they are upon a fox, a hare and a badger Arthritic tree branches twist grotesquely above them in the gloom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something I don't like about this place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too.  No babies to pinch. Haven't pinched a baby in so long, probably lost my touch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything's a joke, Screwball? Laugh your life away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laugh's better'n stubbing your toe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on.  Joke it up while evil magic weaves a spell about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?  Fraid of the big, dark woods?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look! The elf points to a gnarled tree trunk.  At a second glance, it appears to be the body of a man, twisted in petrified pain, his mouth open and howling a silent scream. The three riders draw up short, staring in amazement at the curious shapes of the trees surrounding them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over there!  Another!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is sorcerer's work! All the trees bear an uncanny resemblance to human figure contorted by severe pain.  These are not the curious deformities of nature but actual, living beings transformed into trees. Terrified, Screwball gallops his fox frantically back to the rear of the column.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help!  Jack!  Gump!  Preserve poor me! The other two faeries are quick to follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait!

dialogues.speaker: REAR OF COLUMN
dialogues.text: Jack and Gump ride at the rear of the column, threading single-file along the narrow trail through the dark, forbidding woods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do we follow a raven we can't even see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Send Oona up above the tree tops. She be our eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good plan that. All at once.  Screwball and his two frightened companions come charging down the trail, causing the other faeries t scramble out of their way.  This precipitates a certain grumbling:  "Watch out!  Be careful!  Mind where you're going, etc."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Master Jack!  Master Jack!  These woods are alive!  They're alive!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course they're alive.  All nature is living.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barely living, from the looks of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, no... this is different!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is evil!  Black magic!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorcery!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up ahead!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Gump, let's have a look at this witchcraft. Jack nudges the mare unicorn and she sprints ahead in a gallop.  Gump is right behind, trotting on the colt.  The other three follow, less enthusiastically, on their anima mounts. Once again, the other faeries have to make way on the trail.  This time there is fist shaking and outright epithets as they charge through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swine...!  Toad eaters...! Maggots...!  Vermin...!  etc.  etc...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack pulls the mare to a stop in the grove of malformed trees.  He jumps to the ground and has a closer look at these curiosities.  Gump and the others ride up behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see!  You see!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These chaps'll need a woodpecker to pick their teeth. Jack pauses before a familiar tree, studying the grieved features molded into the bark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, this is King Godwin, Princess Lili's father.  King Godwin and all his mounting party... even the hounds.  See the lymers and alaunts! Jack points to several tree stumps shaped like frantic hounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never cared much for dogs.  Always chasing the wee folk, they are... Think I'll lift my leg on one; see how he likes the tables turned. Screwball saunters over to a dog-shaped root, untying his cod-piece as threatened. Jack draws his gleaming sword.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is ogre's magic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blackheart?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye.  He's enchanted the lot of them.  His reward for delivering the unicorn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Foul fellow, this Couer de Noir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The foulest.  Mayhap I can cut them free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, don't! Gump's warning comes too late.  Jack swings his mighty sword, driving the blade deep into a tree trunk resemblin one of the hunters.  The air is rent by a piercing SCREAM Bright red blood gushes from where the sword cut the bark flowing in a crimson stream down the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear God, forgive me. The sight of the rushing blood unnerves even the boldest faerie.  Screwball fumbles with his cod-piece, full of embarrassment and fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh dear... oh dear... I hope dogs have shorter memories than trees. Jack scrambles on the ground, grabbing up handfuls of mos and mud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry!  Gump, lend a hand. Gump rushes to assist him and they press gobs of moss int the flowing wound.  At first it is like attempting to ste the flood of a leaking dam, the blood continues to ooze through their fingers and pour down the tree.  The contorted expression of the hunter imprisoned within the bark looks evermore tormented.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grunting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Worse than the battlefield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What know you of fields of war?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ofttimes, the wee folk come out to tend the wounded... staunch bleeding with cobwebs... give a parched mouth a sip of dew... cool a fevered brow... The applications of mud and moss begin to work.  The bleeding from the bark abates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There... it seems to quit... I'll wager that war held other attractions quite apart from nursing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... if the knight be already dead; what harm is there in... borrowing a thing or two?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stealing his arms?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can you steal from a man already lost his life?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His honor, I suppose... seeing he no longer can defend it. Jack is disgusted with the faeries.  He picks up his swor and stalks away, leaving Gump and Screwball perplexed by his piety.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The feeble sun is setting, like the pale-yellow yolk of a diseased egg.  A small, swift bird, perhaps a swallow, clips along erratically through the cloudless, pearl-gray sky.

dialogues.speaker: C.U. BIRD
dialogues.text: Oona clings to the back of the darting bird.  Her own gossamer wings, still and half-folded now, resemble those of an exotic butterfly.  She rides the bird as one would flying horse, hanging on to the neck feathers and shading her eyes with her free hand as she strains to observe something moving in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is watching the raven, which no longer resembles a harpy, but is now simply a large, black bird.  It flies with determined wing-beats, straight for a sharply pointe stone pinnacle rising above the treetops.  The raven circles this monument once, then lands on the uppermost crag, folding his wings for the night.

dialogues.speaker: OONA AND THE BIRD
dialogues.text: Holding tight with both hands, Oona urges the bird into a sharp dive.  It swoops like a falling arrow straight into the tangle of tree branches below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack rides silently at the head of the procession.  He seems locked deep within himself.  Gump and Screwball tro alongside, obviously uncomfortable with Jack's somber brooding.  Neither of the faeries has the heart to break the oppressive silence. All at once, the bird darts down out of the trees above, circles twittering, and glides in for a perfect landing o Jack's shoulder.  Oona dismounts; rather, she herself flutters delicately into the air and flies over to Jack's other shoulder.  She caresses his cheek and whispers softly into his ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatiently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's she say...?  What's she say? Oona makes a disagreeable face at Gump.  Jack reaches up and she hops into his hand with a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oona tells me the raven has roosted for the night on a sharp stone spire some half a mile distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be Devil's Needle.  Last landmark I know in these woods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ogg lives there...!  And Thurgis!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Screwball!  Be quiet...!  We have friends live 'neath the Needle. They'll no doubt provide safe refuge for the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beyond Devil's Needle, all is unknown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Needle towers up above the trees straight and smooth, a curiosity of nature resembling a man-made structure. At the base of the rock is the opening to a cave.  With its yawning shape and sharp overhanging row of teeth-like stalactites, it has the appearance of a gigantic, devouring mouth. The faerie troop rides up and dismounts.  A number of human skulls litter the ground, grinning through the curved spokes of several bleached ribcages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twould appear other travelers precede us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nay, Jack, tis not what you're thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I trust our own welcome will be more hospitable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, Jack, it's dwarves live here. Hard-working chaps.  Hammering in the forge all the live-long day. Make the most wondrous things, they do. Jack stoops, picking a skull off the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this?  Some of their handiwork?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nay.  That's but to distract the casual visitor.  A dwarf is too busy to suffer fools gladly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better to kill than be disturbed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your imagination runs away with you, Jack... Those bones be but battlefield gleanings, like I mentioned.  A wee bit of carrion to frighten off the uninvited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here is a bold champion's reward; to serve as a dwarf's doorstop. Jack tosses the skull back to the ground, his face flushe with anger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What care the bones when the soul is free?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scornfully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bah!  You faeries have the morals of ferrets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do the ferrets grave injustice, Jack. (staring into the cave)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But come... best settled 'fore dark. This is inhospitable country at night.  All manner of spriggen and banshee and bogies walk these woods after sunset. Gump leads the way into the cave.  Jack and the others follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stalactites twist down like fangs from above as Gump lead the way through the underground labyrinth.  Screwball walks at his side, a flaming candle-stub stuck to the top of his outlandish Roman helmet.  Jack is right behind and the other faeries are strung out in the rear, some carrying torches, some candle-lanterns, others merely lighting the way with their own mysterious foxfire glow. Turning a final corner, the procession comes to a huge golden gong hanging on the cave wall, a wooden mallet beside it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We wait here.  Those that come this far be considered guests.  The others... well, many false twists and turns lure them astray. Gump delivers the gong a smart mallet blow.  A surprisingly musical note echoes and re-echoes down maze- like passages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice piece of work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pure gold it is... plays a different note every time. Gump strikes the gong again.  The pure, musical sound is indeed different as it reverberates among the stalactites

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See? Gump strikes it a third time.  Another note, even more beautiful, echoes with the sound, forming a melodic chord within the cave. From around the bend a dwarf suddenly appears.  This is OGG.  He is short, muscular fellow with a gray, waist- length beard covering his naked chest.  His leather blacksmith's apron reaches all the way to the ground, concealing his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough... enough... Do you mean to deafen us with your infernal hammering? Gump steps forward and takes the dwarf fondly by the hand

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friend Ogg.  Excuse our enthusiasm, occasioned as it was by a fondness for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honeythorn Gump, is it?  I've not seen your ugly face since you sold me a jug of cow piss claiming it was dragon's tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, bygones're bygones, I always say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or was it the time you and Jimmy Squarefoot stole the golden apples I'd forged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twas Jimmy done that, I merely stood for the blame unfairly... but, here now, Ogg, this be no time to rehash old differences, I've friends along in need of safe haven for the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who might these friends be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Screwball you know, and many other of the wee folk.  We serve as escort for our grand champion, Jack o' the Green. Gump nods at Jack who bows politely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honored to make your acquaintance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grand champion, is it?  And what great cause leads you to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We seek the ogre, Baron Couer de Noir.  He slew a unicorn and plunged the world into eternal winter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thought the weather terrible of late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We seek to undo the curse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gonna make ogre-stew!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any enemy of Blackheart's a friend of mine... Come on then, there's a bit of soup left and clean straw to lie in. Ogg vanishes, abruptly as he came.  Gump motions for the others to follow, leading them around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ogg is far in the distance.  Although his looks are deceptive, he is very agile and makes much better time underground than the other faeries. Suddenly, Jack stops short.  He grabs Gump's arm and points to the sandy cave floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God!  Look!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ogg's footprints!

dialogues.speaker: C.U. FOOTPRINTS
dialogues.text: Etched cleanly in the sand are Ogg's peculiar footprints, leading forward into the depths of the cave.  They are quite obviously the three-pronged prints of a large bird, such as a goose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhh!  Not so loud, mayhap he'll hear ye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwarves be very sensitive about their feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly understandable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very secretive, they are.  Keep their feet covered up.  Best if you don't mention it. Far down the passage, Ogg waves his arm impatiently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Step lively now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His feet shall never cross my lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should hope not!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gump, you're putting words in my mouth. The two hurry along the passageway to catch up with Ogg and the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Words be a far sight better than a dwarf's foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An underground Medieval factory.  A row of glowing open hearth furnaces cast a vivid molten light across a dozen forges.  Everywhere, dwarves are at work, hammering on anvils, heating metal with tongs, pumping bellows and trip-hammers; all wearing beards and floor-length leather aprons.  The ROAR and CLANG of industry fills the air. The faerie troops recline in shadowy niches along the bac wall, eating and getting ready for sleep.  Candles flicker, contrasting with the occasional will-o-the-wisp dazzle of faerie light. Ogg guides Jack and Gump on a tour of the workshop, past bellows and furnaces without a word.  Jack has a bowl of gruel and a wooden spoon.  He eats with relish.  Gump slurps at a dripping honeycomb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ogg leads Jack and Gump to a forge set somewhat apart fro the others.  THURGIS is a hunch-backed dwarf busy shaping a white-hot sword blade on his anvil.  A barely perceptible nod is his only greeting to the visitors. Rows of impeccably finished weapons, spears, swords and axes, stand stacked along the wall.  Hanging above are magnificent golden shields and helmets.  Jack puts down his bowl and examines the weapons as Thurgis plunges his glowing blade into a vat of blood.  The HISS of steam is like a cry of pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jack)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't beat dragon's blood for curing a blade... Cousin Thurgis be co- master here. Thurgis studies the newly-tempered sword-blade, then arches an eyebrow as he regards Jack inspecting the finished goods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Each fit for a hero... My uncle fashioned a hammer for Thor.  Twas he named it Mjolnir.  Grandfather forged Excalibur... You won't ever see finer craftsmanship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, but I have. Smiling, Jack draws his sword and hands it, pommel first, to Thurgis.  The dwarf examines the weapon, admiring the keen edge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How came you by this blade?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I slew the Lindfarne Worm with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack's a grand champion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wields a champion's sword, true. I know the work... fine work... Stagnar's work.  This is the sword called "The Avatar." Thurgis hands Jack back the sword.  He regards it with wonder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Avatar.  I like the sound of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sigurd the Volsung slew Fafnir with that blade... See the line where Regin welded the break? Jack runs his thumb over the weld.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in awe)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sigurd's sword...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another hero's hand-me-down... Thurgis, note the armor; tis Greek work. Thurgis runs his hands over the decorative bas-relief hammered into Jack's breastplate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uhm... fine work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Achilles wore it before the gates of Troy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're well equipped, I'd say. Legendary arms...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Takes more than a good sword to make a hero. Jack slides the sword back in its scabbard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I pray always to be worthy of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stoutly spoke, lad.  These dwarves be sore grouches... Pay no heed to their spiteful grumbling. Gump grabs Jack by the arm and leads him away from the forge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do thank you for your hospitality. The dwarves make no reply, but stand solemnly watching as Gump and Jack leave the workshop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack sits on the straw-pile unbuckling his breastplate. Gump helps him to remove his greaves.  The fabled sword leans an arm-length away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't let this talk of heroes upset you, Jack.  Sigurd's sword is no great thing.  The Volsung killed Fafnir.  You killed Lindfarne. That's one worm apiece... I'd say you and Sigurd were neck-and-neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not in a tournament, Gump. (lying back in the straw)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, but a sword twice tempered in the blood of living dragons...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tis not the sword that counts, but the man what swings it. (Gump rises to leave)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rest easy, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God protect you, Honeythorn Gump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your strong right arm's all the protection I'll need this night. Gump wonders off.  Jack arranges his bedding so it suits him.  He places his sword close by the pillow and turns t blow out the candle.  He is distracted by the glow of faerie light and a musical presence.  This is Oona.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you always sleep with your sword, Jack? Oona kneels beside his bedside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never even had a sword in my hand until yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, tis not for chastity? Methought you kept a naked blade twixt you and any maiden chanced spend the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I live in an abandoned fox den neath the roots of a thousand-year-old oak.  My bed is pine boughs and rabbit skins.  There's no need of weaponry to keep the maids away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm partial to oaks, as are all faerie folk.  Mayn't I come visit sometime?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd be honored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And charmed, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fie!  Don't speak of charms.  I should charm you for being so dull- witted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had no thought of offending you, Oona.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I not please you, Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In every way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And am I not fair?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wondrously so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why do you speak sweeter words to Jenny Greenteeth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was in jest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jest with me then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me I'm fair, as you did the hag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are fair as the first new flower of spring...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And sweet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweeter than bee pollen on a summer wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pray you be sweet as your words, dear Jack. Oona moves close to Jack, kissing his lips as a soft cocoon of faerie light engulfs them.  Nearly enchanted, Jack pushes away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nay, Oona, tis not possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A faerie's love makes anything possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm promised to another!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What shape I take matters not.  Long you for another?  I'll give you your heart's desire. The faerie light burns brightly around Oona, surrounding her like a chrysalis as she alters and shifts, transforming into a grown woman.  When she steps forward, parting the curtain of light like a niade stepping throug a waterfall, it is the Princess Lili who appears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lili!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come then, Green Jack, you've promises to keep... Oona/Lili moves closer to Jack, running her hand behind his neck, embracing him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... this isn't real...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, but it is... I'm warm and alive and happy to be in your arms. Furiously, Jack thrusts her aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll not be enchanted!  This is foul magic...!  What an abhorrent creature would I be to dally with faeries guised as my beloved when the Princess herself has suffered God knows what fate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (harsh and spiteful)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I could show you that fate... Your precious princess!  I wish you could see her now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lili has completely transformed into a savage beast.  Fur covers her face, her ears are pointed.  Sharp fangs punctuate her lips.  Only her eyes still seem human and afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very frightened)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please... kill me if you must... It would be a gift. PULL BACK to show the dark room, windows shrouded by heav black drapes.  Thousands of candles drip and sputter, casting a flickering light across the clammy stone walls. The Baron stands before the cowering Lili, wearing his mask and wrapped in his cloak.  In his gloved right hand he holds a whip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My generosity is not so large as that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your words sting more sharply than your whip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I speak of love, and you think only of the lash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are cruel!  Your heartless jesting worse than torture!  How can you speak of love when you see what I am!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like well what I see.  It pleases me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm hideous!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're magnificent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grotesque... monstrous...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the contrary!  The puling, pallid creature you were before was truly something disgusting.  Now you are splendid... a fierce goddess... the embodiment of all that is strong and beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lie!  You wish to humiliate me, as if the form I'm forced to bear were not punishment enough!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should glory in your animal nature.  It is your triumph!  None know that better than I! The Baron rips off his mask.  Beneath is a savage face, half-wolf, half-goat, with a pair of curling horns poised above.  Lili SCREAMS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God protect me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not from me, surely...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You... you're a beast!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're all of us beasts, my dear. Only most are afraid to show it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you... are you not also afraid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am afraid of nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why hide behind a mask?  You are ashamed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know no more of shame than I do of fear.  I wear this mask not for concealment but protection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Protection?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am a creature of darkness.  I require the shadow's solace and the black of night... Sunlight is abhorrent to me... I cover myself completely whenever I venture forth in daylight... Sunshine is my destroyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like some vile toadstool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I prefer to think, more like the sagacious owl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you feed on mice and rats?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I prefer a plump capon, but will happily serve you rats if they're to your liking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why have you brought me here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To be my bride, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd soon die. The Baron uncoils his sinister whip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is your choice, my dear.  A wedding will be far more swift, I assure you. The Baron strikes out at Lili with his whip.  It cracks i the air close by her and she leaps back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're both of us damned, my beauty. Lili rushes to the window and pulls apart the heavy black drapes.  A shaft of sunlight knifes across the shadowy room and strikes the Baron like a bolt from Heaven.  He reels from the force, grimacing in pain.  There is a note of triumph is Lili's shrill laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toadstool! The Baron cringes in the light.  He lifts his thick cloak to shield himself and quickly pulls on his mask.  This done, he retrieves his whip and advances on the cowering princess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bold and plucky.  I admire your spirit, Princess, almost as much as I lust for your savage, feline beauty. Princess Lili jumps up onto the window ledge, glancing down at the rocks far below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not afraid to jump.  I'd prefer that to being with you! The Baron makes no reply, but strikes unexpectedly with his whip.  The lash coils around Lili's neck and pulls he off balance, yanking her back into the room.  She falls o her knees at the Baron's feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When the time's come, you won't need to jump, I'll throw you out myself!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do it now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Now is the time for discipline. Some lessons in obedience for the future Baroness. The Baron slashes Lili cruelly with the whip.  She CRIES OUT in pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not as sweet as my caress. The Baron strikes her again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack... Oh, Jack... Help me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too bad your precious Jack can't hear you... the damsel in distress... A rescue attempt would be most amusing... We could flay sweet Jack alive as an after-dinner entertainment... The Baron punctuates each bitter phrase with a stroke of the lash.  Lili lies bleeding on the floor, WEEPING helplessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SOUND of Lili's weeping CARRIES OVER as we SEE Oona, huddled in the corner of Jack's niche, crying softly to herself.  She has resumed her faerie shape and the light which emanates from her fragile wings and body is of a tender, delicate hue.  Jack kneels solicitously before her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oona... don't cry... please, you mustn't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weeping)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You... you... you mortal you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sobbing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should I feel such pain?  Should be the other way round... I could vex you... make you dance your life away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Threats won't make me love you.  Tis not the way of the human heart. Oona rises in a rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What care I for the human heart! Such a soft, spiritless thing it is. I prefer the hearts of hawks and wolves; fierce and free and keen as steel!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And as barren of love as stone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would build a wall around me with such stone, so the likes of you might never enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be fair, Oona.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You beware, Jack!  You and your porridge-pot heart! There is a bright whirlwind of faerie light, and in a brilliant, pyrotechnic moment, Oona is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oona...?  Oona, are you still here? Blast! Jack arranges his cloak as a bed-cover and settles down for the night, drawing his sword and resting it beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hard enough to fathom a women's mind, what chance has one with a faerie? Jack blows out his candle.  Blackness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the next morning.  The faerie army is preparing for the march, donning armor and putting a keen edge on this weapons.  Jack is mounted on Sapphire, resplendent in Achilles' armor.  Gump brushes the coat of the foal.  Ogg Thurgis and several other dwarves have assembled to see them off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make haste!  We've a hard day's march ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be gentle with them, Jack.  They only march to please you.  Were this a faerie journey, we'd ride the wind on thistledown and ragwort stems. Thurgis and Ogg approach.  Thurgis carries a large, round golden shield.  Ogg has something concealed behind his back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (clearing his throat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahem...!  I'm naught for fancy words, work as I do with my hands. The world needs champions and I favor that... Thurgis hands the gleaming shield up to Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wrought this shield for noble Tristan ere fate o'ertook him... No blade nor axe can dent it.  I believe it will serve you well. Jack straps the shield over his back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I pray always to be worthy of it and thank you well, Thurgis. Ogg steps forward and hands two glittering objects to Gump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baron Couer de Noir is a blight 'gainst all nature.  We dwarves be not fighters; still we are with you in this battle.  Some of our handiwork may be of assistance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We be honored, friend Ogg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a coil of golden thread fine as spider web yet naught can break it... and a silver key no lock can resist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're with us in battle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May God protect you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye, and valor select you. Oona flies down abruptly from above the trees.  Without looking directly at Jack, she addresses the assembled faerie warriors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The raven has taken to wing and flies due north! Jack waves his arm at the assembled troop of faeries and urges the unicorn to the head of the column.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Onward to victory! The entire troop gives out with a rousing CHEER as it set forward on the final trek through the forbidding forest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trees are twisted and grotesque.  A dense undergrowth of tangled vines studded with six-inch thorns block the troop's progress like over-sized concertina wire.  Jack rides at the head of the column, hacking a pathway throug the vines with his enchanted sword.  Gump rides just behind, doing his best with his tiny battleaxe to clean u the excess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... this rate... we'll all be in our graves... 'fore we reach the Baron's fortress...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll surely be in our graves if we don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Going grows slower... we've not made... half a mile in two hours... Jack continues slashing at the serpentine vines.  A final vigorous sword-stroke reveals a frozen meadow; broad, open, and inviting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gump, look! Jack urges the unicorn forward into the meadow.  Gump and the remainder of the troop follow.  At the far end of the clearing a row of cliffs stand like the ramparts of a city.  Sheer and impassable, save for a narrow defile across which something very like a vast silver curtain hangs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God's blessing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's the way, mates. Jack gallops forward across the meadow, followed close behind by the cheering faeries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The faerie troops rein in a hundred yards from the opening.  The silver curtain is now quite clearly SEEN as a gigantic spider web, the gossamer strands inches thick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What make ye of that, Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It bodes evil. Oona swoops down from above, hovering in the air before the faerie column.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scolding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this a May Day pageant?  Are you all off on a lark...?  The raven passed this way hours ago!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heading north still?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: True north... (she points)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Straight up that pass, through the net.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it a net, then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some sort of net... I'll see. Oona flies rapidly away, straight towards the web.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (alarmed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willful creature, that one...

dialogues.speaker: OONA'S FLIGHT
dialogues.text: Oona makes a bee-line for the web.  She drives fearlessly ahead, without caution, flying straight into the center o the weave.  Landing on the strands, she is immediately stuck.

dialogues.speaker: OONA IN WEB
dialogues.text: The more Oona struggles, the more entangled she becomes. Like a trapped fly, her frenzied attempts set the entire web trembling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help!  I'm stuck...!  Oh please help! A giant spider the size of a man makes his way along the web towards the helpless Oona.  There is something especially repulsive about the creature's monstrous shape.  His movements are a coordinated ballet of evil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screaming)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please...!  Jack!  Help me...! Don't let it touch me...!

dialogues.speaker: JACK AND THE FAERIES
dialogues.text: Jack draws his sword, calling to his troops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry!  Save her! Suddenly, a staghorn beetle large as a rhinoceros lumbers out of the concealing bushes at the base of the cliff. Its black, armored wing-plates gleam like polished steel. The forked, six-foot horn towers above its head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance! A young goblin lance-bearer hurries forward with Jack's lance, handing it up to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Archers!  Bring down that spider! I'll deal with this other creature...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay on your guard, Jack.  The bug is enchanted surely. Jack sheathes his sword, lowers his lance, and spurring the unicorn with a kick of his heels, charges straight at the giant beetle. The goblin archers rush forward shouting towards the cliff. Jack rides straight at the big beetle.  His lance strikes the hard carapace of the thorax and glances off, doing no harm. Jack wheels the unicorn around and charges a second time. The lance hits the wing-casing and shatters.  Jack is thrown from his mount.  The evil beetle closes on him, pincers opening and closing like some grotesque engine of war.

dialogues.speaker: THE WEB
dialogues.text: The spider is nearly upon Oona as the archers line up below.  A hail of arrows hit the mark.  The spider reacts with spasms of pain as they stud into him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Kill it... Kill it! The arrows don't stop the spider and it reaches Oona, biting her in the leg.  She screams into unconsciousness. The spider sets to work spinning filament and wrapping th stunned faerie up like a cocoon.

dialogues.speaker: JACK AND THE BEETLE
dialogues.text: Jack scrambles to his feet, drawing his sword just as the beetle is upon him.  A furious backhand slash lops off on of the insect's antennae.  This doesn't slow it down; it continues to pursue the back-pedaling Jack, pincers clicking together like twin scythes.  Jack parries and stabs, slashing at the beetle with his sword. A well-aimed thrust takes off half the beetle's foreleg. Quantities of foul, black blood gush forth onto the ground.

dialogues.speaker: THE ARCHERS
dialogues.text: The goblin marksmen continue to pour a steady rain of arrows into the spider.  The swollen abdomen bristles wit dozens of accurate hits. Two oversized wasps, each with a six-foot wingspan, dive down on the archers.  They scatter much as soldiers of a later age will react to a strafing by aircraft. One unfortunate pixie bowman is seized by a wasp and born aloft.  The wasp curls his abdomen beneath him.  The barbed stinger emerges like a harpoon.  The helpless, screaming pixie is stung through.  The wasp releases the lifeless body and it drops back to earth.

dialogues.speaker: JACK AND THE BEETLE
dialogues.text: Jack continues to retreat before the beetle's advance, slashing with his sword.  The second antennae is neatly amputated, without any effect on the giant insect. Stepping backwards, Jack's foot goes into a hole and he i twisted off-balance and falls.  The big bug's shadow darkens over him.  The wicked pincers CLINK.

dialogues.speaker: THE MARE UNICORN
dialogues.text: as she lowers her horned head and charges the beetle. Running straight and true as a fighting bull, the unicorn drives into the side of the bug.  The long, spiraling hor catches the joint between abdomen and thorax, sliding easily into the creature's side.  The massive insect whip about in agony, snapping at the unicorn.  Sapphire dances adroitly back out of harm's way. The interlude gives Jack the time to regain his feet. Rushing forward, he stabs his sword into the space betwee the insect's head and thorax.  The pincers open and close helplessly.  It is all over.  Jack stabs the sword in a second time.  The big bug collapses. Jack runs to Sapphire and vaults onto her back.  With a victorious WAR CRY he charges forward to help the beleaguered archers.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHERS AND WASPS
dialogues.text: Jack is attacked from above by one of the wasps.  It hovers above, seeking either to sting him or pluck him from his mount.  Jack wheels the unicorn about in a tight circle.  The wasp circles overhead.  With a sudden, overhand slash, Jack strikes the wasp's basketball-sized head from his droning body.  The head drops like a stone. The body continues to fly in erratic circles, like a pilot-less aircraft, until it crashes, BUZZING, to earth. The disorganized faeries CHEER loudly as Jack rides up to assist them.  The surviving wasp harasses them from above

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't aim for the body, the armor is too strong... aim for the chinks... shoot at the spaces between... The archers rally and aim as Jack instructed.  Although the first arrows miss the mark, a second round is more accurate.  The wasp is hit repeatedly between its body sections.  Mortally wounded, it falls thrashing to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: JACK AT THE WEB
dialogues.text: Jack urges Sapphire to the base of the cliff as the gobli archers dispatch the wounded wasp.  Sword high, he leaps down and rushes to where several of the web's anchor strands are fastened.  From his life in the wild, Jack knows certain strands are not sticky so the spider won't get caught in his own contrivance.  Jack checks a strand but gets stuck and only pulls free with difficulty.  He tries another and finds it clean. Sheathing his sword, Jack climbs the web, hauling himself up the uncoated strand like a sailor ascending the ratlines of a ship. The spider, though wounded, spins a shroud for the haples Oona and does not notice Jack's approach.  Jack draws his sword and thrusts up into the arachnid's arrow-studded belly.  The huge spider whips about in pain.  Jack strike him again, slicing off one of his eight legs.  Frantic, the spider charges.  The Green Man stands his ground and splits the spider's head in two with a mighty stroke. The spider drops, falling past Jack, hanging-up in his ow web below.  Jack climbs to where Oona is bound, cutting her cocoon free from the web. Jack carriers the silken-wrapped Oona back down.

dialogues.speaker: JACK AND FAERIES
dialogues.text: Jack lays Oona's shrouded form on the ground and is immediately surrounded by the faeries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well done, lad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three cheers for our champion. The faeries give out with a hearty HOORAY as Jack works deftly with his sheath-knife, slicing the gossamer webbin from around the unconscious Oona.  He severs the last strand and lifts her from the confining cocoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is she... dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thank the Lord, but she be sore envenomed by the spider's bite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're blind now.  Oona was our eyes and ears.  How do we find the Castle Couer de Noir without her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll find it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easily said... the raven passed this way hours ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heading true north.  We continue in that direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never knowing when it takes a turn or changes course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll trust in faith, Gump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye, lad... we've little else to go by. The goblins and faeries have prepared a small litter from two lances and a woolen cloak.  Three faeries lift Oona and place her on the litter.  Her face is serene, as if she were sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gently, boys... go easy with her. Jack draws his sword and chops through the bottom of the web, opening a passage into the defile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (barking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, men!  Let's bury our dead and be on our way!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The column of armed faeries marches steadily up the defile.  Jack rides at the head; Gump beside him on the colt.  Four faeries bear the litter, carrying Oona on their shoulders.  In the distance behind them are four small, flower-decked mounds:  the freshly dug graves in which their fallen comrades lie buried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like some deformed and dying organism, the towers and twisted turrets of the Baron's castle are silhouetted against the night sky.  Utterly sinister in its malformed splendor, the building's shape suggests the embodiment of pure evil.  High in the uppermost tower, a single light gleams through a slitted window. Winging silently towards the castle, the coal-black raven glides through the night like an angel from Hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dripping tallow candles cast flickering shadows across th mossy walls of the Baron's lab.  All manner of arcane instruments; astrolabs, crucibles, retorts and furnaces, are crammed into the narrow room.  Stuffed owls and crocodiles hang from the ceiling.  The Baron, unmasked an wearing the flowing black robes of a master magician, is busy with an experiment.  The table he works on crawls with toads and lizards; a large crucible drips blood. Several IMPS and DEMONS serve as the Baron's assistants, scurrying about the lab like characters from a Bosch painting.  All are deformed, mutant creatures.  They crackle and snigger like the inhabitants of a zoological madhouse. The Baron takes up a glass container filled with eyeballs and pours them into his bloody cauldron, muttering to himself, his horned, lupine head fierce as Lucifer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muttering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blind eyes, blind eyes, what do you see...?  The future's secrets belong to me... A deformed imp with the head and goggling eyes of a fish, fidgets at the Baron's side.  His evil master cuffs him and barks an order:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Batwing...!  Bring me batwing, oaf. Be quick about it! The imp scampers off, searching among the musty jars and canisters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And leper's thumb...!  Be swift, before the mixture cools! All at once, the raven flies into the room, flapping in circles around the lab before coming to rest on the Baron's shoulder. The raven rasps into the Baron's ear like a back-fence gossip.  The Baron listens and nods, completely familiar with the language of birds.  His reaction is one of vast amusement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An army of faeries...!  How very droll... Do they carry flowers stead of spears? (the raven croaks)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, real spears, they mean to be taken seriously... (the raven croaks again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A boy riding a unicorn...?  Things are getting serious indeed. The Baron paces his laboratory, the raven riding on his shoulder.  He pauses by a shelf where a bouquet of black roses stands in a vase crafted from a human skull.  The Baron selects a single ebony blossom and sniffs it pensively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So... the faeries are marching... if by some miracle they get past the insects... we'll have a surprise ready... The Baron crushes the black rose in his fist.  When he opens his hand, the blossom has been magically transforme into a hideously deformed bat.  The bat unfolds its wings revealing toad-like gargoyle's features and a long, forke reptilian tail.  The grinning mouth is studded with tiny, needle-sharp teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... you'll do nicely... very nicely.  Just the sort of creature to rip a faerie to shreds... The bat-demon takes wing and circles the lab, diving suddenly at the fish-headed imp, who SCREAMS in terror. The bat fastens himself on the shrieking imp, tearing wit his tiny teeth.  The imp waves his arms frantically in a futile effort to dislodge the creature.  Blood flows.  Th Baron's cruel LAUGHTER ECHOES in the vaulted room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A heavy mist shrouds the twisted trees, blunting their agonized shapes as if in pity.  The Baron's demonic LAUGHTER CARRIES OVER and merges with the raucous CALLING of crows.  A flight of the black birds passes through the fog, appearing suddenly, then fading just as abruptly int the gray. The SOUND of marching men is HEARD.  A moment later, the faerie troop is glimpsed, trudging forward out of the mist.  Jack and Gump ride at the head of the dispirited column.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not admit it, Honeythorn Gump. We've lost our way entirely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long as we don't lose heart, Jack...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll never find the Baron's castle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once you thought we'd never find the Greek's armor and look at ye now, decked out like a proper hero.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wind parts the mist ahead on the trail and for just a moment a hideous form is glimpsed.  Shaped like a hunchback with overlong arms, the creature has the head o a boar, with a long, flattened snout and curved tusks. This is JIMMY SQUAREFOOT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold!  What manner of demon be this?

dialogues.speaker: JACK AND GUMP
dialogues.text: Jack draws his gleaming sword.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nay.  This time we strike first! Jack kicks the unicorn's flanks and gallops ahead down th trail, brandishing his sword.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, no! Gump urges the colt into a fast run and hurries after Jack. The pig-headed creature darts off the trail and sprints into the woods.  Jack is right behind, the unicorn swift as the wind.  Which-ever way the creature turns in his frantic effort to escape, the unicorn leaps ahead, cuttin him off. A projecting tree-root catches the creature's foot and sends him sprawling.  Jack leaps down, sword in hand and rushes up for the kill. The creature snuffles and grunts with fear as Jack stands over him, poised for the killing thrust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No hurt Jimmy, sir... oh no, please, sir...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sending you back to Hell! Gump gallops up breathlessly on the colt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold, Jack!  Don't strike!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nay.  I show no pity to imps and fiends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know the rogue, Jack.  Tis Jimmy Squarefoot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, poor Jimmy... never hurt no one...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He be a frightful-looking sod, tis true, but harmless for all that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he a friend, then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, yes... Jimmy Squarefoot good friend to one and all...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's no enemy, that's sure. Jack relents and sheathes his terrible sword.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive my blood haste, Jimmy Squarefoot, but I want no more surprises from Couer de Noir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Black Baron, you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye.  We be on a quest to set the world aright --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But seem to have gotten lost on the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Much good we do the world, for all our noble quest...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy Squarefoot no lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, clap yourself on the back then, mate, and point the way to Castle Couer de Noir. Jimmy Squarefoot gets to his feet, dusts himself off with dignity, and with exaggerated formality, extends his arms and points into the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simple as that, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Castle Couer de Noir built with magic... simple as death... strong as hate...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bewildered)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do know where it is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hear him out, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Many time Jimmy Squarefoot try find a way inside... many, many time... Plenty treasure there, oh plenty, plenty... It a bad place... blacker than the Baron's heart...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you show us the way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To Castle Couer de Noir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There'll be spoils aplenty if you guide us there.  Once we breach the walls, help yourself to all you can carry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That very nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you do it, Jimmy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way over walls... too much magic...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let that be our problem, just get us there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You follow. Jimmy Squarefoot starts off in the direction he pointed, his odd, loping gait more animal than human.  Jack looks doubtfully at Gump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we trust him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... but what choice have we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Follow Jimmy Squarefoot. Jack waves his arms, signaling the troops to advance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On to Castle Couer de Noir! The troop follows Jack and Gump as they ride after Jimmy Squarefoot into the fog-shrouded woods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SNAP of a whip is as abrupt as the change of scene. A vile stone cellar, walls dripping with moss and slime. Human bones litter the earthen floor.  Chains and shackle hang between the instruments of torture:  there is an Iro Maiden, a rack and a charcoal brazier heating various tongs and pincers. The whip CRACKS again as the SHADOW of the Baron moves across the wall. Princess Lili is chained to a stone pillar.  Clothed only in tatters, her glossy pelt striped with bloody welts fro the lash, she huddles helplessly before the fury of the Baron. The Baron strikes again with the whip.  Semi-conscious, Lili can do little more than whimper when she is hit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your moans seem almost pleasurable, my dear... developing a taste for the lash?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (groaning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kill me... I want... so nice...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should I kill you? (strikes her again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A simple course in etiquette... something your parents sadly overlooked. The Baron slashes at her with the whip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No more... please...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can keep a victim alive for weeks... months, if I desire it... it's an art.  They beg for death... I keep it just out of their reach. (he strikes her with the whip)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pain remains constant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't please... I'll do what you desire... The Baron coils his whip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweet Princess, you begin to sound most reasonable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want from me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the moment, very little.  Your company at my table... The Baron beckons and a squat imp with the features of a bullfrog scurries out of the shadows and unfastens the shackles binding Lili.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll get you cleaned up, find a suitable gown... I imagine you'll enjoy a good meal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few day's nourishment will see your strength returning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What will become of me then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you are ripe for my pleasure, I will enjoy the harvest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm pleased you're not troubled by the prospect...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do as you wish with my body, you'll never possess my soul!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your soul...?  Why should I bother with such a paltry trifle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't expect you'd understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear Princess, the human soul is a highly elusive commodity.  I suggest you spend some hours before the glass.  Contemplate your intriguing reflection and consider whether such a creature as yourself could possibly possess something as fine and beautiful as a soul. The Baron pulls a hand-mirror from beneath his robe and hands it to Lili.  She refuses to look at herself, castin the glass aside in a rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a beast!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed I am, my dear... that makes us a pair! The Baron's lupine features appear even more demonic as h LAUGHS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small fire blazes under an ice-coated tree.  The faerie troop huddles about it in their robes for warmth. Deformed like a torture victim, Castle Couer de Noir is silhouetted against the frozen sky. Gump and Jimmy Squarefoot sit on a fallen log next to Jack, who stares gloomily at the hideous fortress beyond the trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shivering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never felt so cold in all me born days...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chill is worse this night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It be the castle... we feel the castle... it be that close...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A castle's but stone and mortar --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nay.  Castle Couer de Noir is Devil's work... built with sorrow and grief...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't like the feel of it, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your own fear troubles you... We're here, aren't we?  For all the dark magic protecting it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The walls be glued together with blood and tears... the wind in the basement cries with pain...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mayhap the Baron wanted us to find him.  What good is magic if you don't make use of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give in to despair and all is lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It feels wrong, Jack... like a trap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's more than one way to spring a trap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye, so long as you're not too greedy for the bait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plenty treasure inside... Jimmy seen it once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been inside?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't speak to me of dreams!  I feel I've been dreaming since the unicorn was killed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That be so, better you pinch yourself now, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
